US.STROPHE:
Where are those of our village
people of our community?
Come let us weave the lament
let us sing the mourning song
US.COMMENTAIRE: Poem recited by the officiants (to minaa) Ne' Ambaa and Ne' Sulo, during the death ritual of Indo' Serang, Ne' Banne' s daughter, 14 October 1993, at Randanan (Rindingallo). Indo' Serang was a to burake, officiant for the rituals of the rising sun (or East rituals). - 2. Saroan: mutual aid organization in a village, set up for ritual or agricultural work. This opening line is often replaced by to mai sang banuanta 'those from our hamlet'. - 4. Balandong: from badong 'round dance for the deceased'.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Landscape in the northern territory, around Sapan.

US.STROPHE:
The lament that takes turns
mourning song that alternates
Lament as substitute for our grief
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 5. Salo: to stamp on the ground. Si-: prefix with meaning of reciprocity and alternation. - 6. Rio, mario: sadness. Lamban: to surpass limits, without limits, without order, to mix. To mix in order to soften. Another translation is: that sadness being exchanged. - 7. Bating: lament spoken by women. Here, the officiant (to minaa) forgets a line generally coupled with line 7: sibala'na rio- rio, a line with the same meaning as the preceding one.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Women badong singers, village of Penduan Ra'ba, 2001.

US.STROPHE:
Is there anyone who does not feel love
No love for their mother?
We are the ones who feel love
love for our mother

Mother, listen to us here
incline your ears this way
So we may arrange your lament
and make you a good mourning song
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 13. Mati': towards the addressee, towards outside.

US.STROPHE:
Mother, make the sun shine
spread its rays to the edge of the sky
Scatter the chaff
blow away the dead leaves
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 19. Soyok: husk of the rice.

US.STROPHE:
So that I arrange for you the lament
and make your mourning song good
Lament as substitute for our grief

I will have reached your birth
the time of your creation
Then you were conceived
when you were perfectly formed
US.COMMENTAIRE: 28. Tampa 'to give birth, to build, to shape'.

US.STROPHE: Didn't the langsat bear fruit? wasn't the durian ladened? wasn't fruit everywhere?
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 29. Langsat (langsat domesticum): the tree and the fruit, of small size, yellow, with white and juicy flesh. In the past this tree was planted close to the menhir (erected for a deceased person of high rank) where the buffaloes were killed (Veen 1965, The Merok Feast of the Sa'dan Toraja, Nijhoff, line 661). - 30. Durian (Durio zibethinus): the tree and the fruit. Huge tree (Malvacees) from the Indian archipelago. Its fruit, as big as a small melon, can be eaten. The fruit is inside a thorny husk. Meaning of the strophe: during pregnancy, nature's fertility participates in the fecundity of this mother.

US.STROPHE:
Not mangoes neither large nor small
not a single kind of mango
was what her mother was eating
US.COMMENTAIRE: Ambang, pao and dadeko all designate mangoes. Ambang (ambawang, ambayang): large mango with a smell rather like turpentine reserved for the officiated women at the bua' kasalle ritual - the to tumbang, the young women and girls who are taboo at the bua' feast and who must remain in the house of the feast-giver for a specific period of time (Veen 1966, The Sa'dan Toradja Chant for the Deceased, Nijhoff: 22).

US.STROPHE:
Gold was her pregnancy craving
for the necklace, her mouth watered
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 36. Rara': necklace consisting of three wooden cylinders covered in gold, metaphor for high class women (Nooy-Palm 1969, 'Dress and Adornment of the Sa'dan Toradja'. Tropical Man: 173.) - Toraja language does not distinguish gender. In the following strophes, the feminine pronoun is used because the deceased is a woman. In the whole passage we found that the needs of the pregnant woman were extraordinary.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Rara': necklace, with three wooden cylinders covered in gold, Ke'te' Kesu', 2005.

US.STROPHE:
We'll talk about this up until the end
for whom chicken eggs were requested
for whom clay was fetched
One for whom buffalo milk was boiled
who was nourished with glutinous rice
who was formed with coagulated milk
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 37. In 2005,Ne' Lumbaa made the following comment about this line: 'Susimo kada tomatua to la. Nakombong lan tambuk. Kombonganna bangsia sanganna to. Puang matua na kombong lan tambuk'. 'These are the words of the ancestors. It grows inside the womb. It is called pregnancy. It is also called a pregnancy. The Old Gold (Puang Matua) has created her inside a womb.' - 39. During pregnancy, Toraja women sometimes eat earth (atena padang). - 40. Bumbungan: 'milk, coagulated milk'. Makko: 'tough, coagulated'. Referring to this passage, Ne' Lumbaa explains that the child is made in the womb.

US.STROPHE:
She was said to be of exceptional form
her fashioning was extraordinary
her creation difficult to achieve

Her creation was far away
difficult even for an eagle
Will she be reached there up there?
will she be met there?
will she have be attained?
US.COMMENTAIRE: Ne' Lumbaa' commented on this strophe: 'up in the sky, in the womb'. The sky represents here the womb.

US.STROPHE:
Up at the top of the sky
one who is born at the peak
Who appears at the highest point
at the very summit
US.COMMENTAIRE: She is so high that she cannot be seen.

US.STROPHE:
Created at the place of bracelets
gold crafted as beautifully as possible
the mixture perfectly formed
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 55. Rara': necklace with three wooden cylinders covered with gold, metaphor for high class women (Nooy-Palm 1969, 'Dress and Adornment of the Sa'dan Toradja'. Tropical Man: 173.)

US.STROPHE:
Her birth was delayed
becoming human was difficult

They called the ones who know
they brought in the eloquent ones
They came, selecting the ritual deeds
determining the ritual speech
So that the deeds are clearly segmented
and the speech ordered in rows
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 62. Umbille: 'to delouse, to dig to find'. The officiants choose the rite according to the social status of the child.

US.STROPHE:
Already affirmed as face of the moon
and acknowledged as rays of the sun
she has just revealed herself
US.COMMENTAIRE: Barrena allo ('rays of the sun') and lindona bulan ('face of the moon') form a pair referring to noble status. - 68. Kinda': rolling-up movement outwards suggestive of giving birth.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Pattern of the sun on a house gable.

US.STROPHE:
So that the bobbin may slide in and out
and the weaving be straight
the threads be not tangled
US.COMMENTAIRE: In Austronesian looms, a long sword-shaped piece of wood allowing the threads to be held: a sort of fine wooden sabre used for the loom.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: In a Torajan loom, the piece of wood balida held by the weaver Yuli Galugu, Sangkombong, Sa'dan, 2005.
In a Torajan loom, the piece of wood balida held by the weaver Yuli Galugu.

US.STROPHE:
Born to the sounds of tinkling
brought forth with clickety clacking
curved like a shrimp sieve
US.COMMENTAIRE: This tercet may be reminiscent of the weeping of the infant, compared to the sound of swarming crustaceans and a noise-making scarecrow (rengo-rengo). Lummi 'sieve, landing net'.

US.STROPHE:
A birth that astonishes
a creation that is amazing
her fashioning is wondrous
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 77. Tampa 'to give birth, to make, to shape'.

US.STROPHE:
Her umbilical cord red like embers
her afterbirth crimson like cordyline
her placenta flashes like lightning
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 78. Lolo 'placenta, umbilical cord'. - 79. The plant tabang (Cordyline terminalis) has leaves as red as blood. Used in the maro ritual, during flagellation, it was brought from the sky to cure humans.

US.STROPHE:
An iron spade is forged
a hole is dug in the sky
the ixora is uprooted
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 83. Padang-padang: Ixora coccinea, ixore plants, herbs also known as lamban lalan ('road crossing').

US.STROPHE:
Place where the umbilical cord is planted
where the placenta is placed in the ground
US.COMMENTAIRE: Toraja bury the placenta and umbilical cord (lolo pia-pia) alongside the eastern part of the house (matallo ulunna padang 'to the rising sun upstream the field'). Each placenta is buried from downriver to upriver, in front of every pillar, with a mixture of iron, beads and leaves (passakke, ra'pak-ra'pak, darinding), in order to bring positive attributes to the child in terms of his mood, character, and prosperity.

US.STROPHE: The umbilical transformed into a sarita fabric the afterbirth assumes the form of a maa' cloth Spread out to bring forth wealth in safekeeping so it will grow tall So that she will grow big so that she will thrive
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 87. Maa' are usually wide rectangles of cloth in varying size. Sarita, by contrast are long, narrow fabrics. Imported maa' come from India via Java. Imported sarita are of Dutch origin. Those made locally are shorter than the imported one. Maa' are considered holier than sarita. Sarita are used at rituals of both the rising and setting sun (Gittinger 1989: 166). The placenta and umbilical cord can have similar magical powers (Veen 1966: 29).

US.STROPHE:
Growing held in the lap of ritual deeds
thriving supported by ritual speech
cradled by the ancestral model
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 92. Aluk: ritual law, rituals. - 94. Sangka': ancestral model.

US.STROPHE:
Growing in the lap of the rites of the fine-toothed comb
thriving supported by the rites of cleansing
cradled by the fragrant ceremonial grass
US.COMMENTAIRE: - Sara'ka': a comb used to weave a cloth. - Suru': 1) 'comb' 2) small ritual carried out at home, to purify oneself with a with a chicken sacrifice offered to divinities and ancestors, by giving its flesh mixed with dianella grass. The chicken feathers are then hung in the house, with the banana leaves used for the offering. The meaning of a comb may be linked to an old ritual, still found in the Morowali district. The Wana from Central Sulawesi still go to the river and recount their disorders by holding a comb in the water (G. Nougarol, personal communication). - Pa'takarian: from tagari (Dianella ensifolia), fragrant ceremonial grass cooked with the chicken in the sacrificial ritual.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Burake Ne' Lumbaa sacrificing a chicken for the ritual tumangke suru', 2005.
Ne' Lumbaa looking at the entrails of the chicken, 2005.
Ne' Lumbaa making an offering to the divinities, oriented towards the rising sun, 2005.

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: Down from the sky in procession through bua' ritual

US.STROPHE:
A truly beautiful heavenly village
a wonderful house indeed
the glorious ritual grounds
US.COMMENTAIRE: Lines common to the ossoran badong and gelong maro, when the woman in trance remembers.

US.STROPHE:
Nearly staying up above
almost not returning home
not coming back like an upside down bamboo
US.COMMENTAIRE: The deceased, coming from the sky to earth, is compared to a divinity. - 103. The image of the bamboo upside down is explained by the use of two types of bamboo during the rituals. Tallang dipatuo is a bamboo cut during the rituals of the East (rising sun) and tallang dipamate is cut and turned upside down to hold the palm wine, for drinking.

US.STROPHE:
Upriver, the ritual deeds as our bridge
ritual speech as our ladder
ancestral model as our rope

Upriver, the rites of the fine-toothed comb as the bridge
the rites of cleansing as the ladder
the fragrant ceremonial grass as the rope
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 109. Pa'takarian, from tagari (Dianella ensifolia), fragrant ceremonial grass cooked with the chicken in the offering ritual, see 97.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Ne' Lumbaa performs a ritual of offering and prayer (suru') by means of a chicken sacrifice, in the direction of the rising sun.

US.STROPHE:
Upriver, the palm tree as the bridge
the decorated one as the ladder
the heavenward pole as the rope
US.COMMENTAIRE: The three strophes show that the deceased, who comes from the sky, is called by the officiants through rituals, speech, palm decorations and all types of vertical symbols. During the bua' kasalle ritual, lumbaa langi' (from langi' 'sky') is a pole planted in the center of the ceremonial space. The officiants go up to a high platform where they will declaim praises. - 110. Pusuk: the leaves of induk, the sugar palm tree (Arenga pinnata).

MEDIA.LEGENDE: 'Celestial pole' (lumbaa langi'), tall bamboo erected during the bua' kasalle ritual, Deri (Sesean), 1993.

US.STROPHE:
Marching in procession from up there
does the bracelet just descend?
Does the gold simply go?
standing up to leave just like that?

She marches with the beating of the gong
she goes down with various sounds
standing up people carrying things for her
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 117. Gong, especially for noblemen, are not made locally; they probably come from outside Sulawesi, Java or Malaysia.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: A kettle gong hanging in a house, Sangngalla', 2001.

US.STROPHE: Led by the one who knows followed by the eloquent one Led by 'the mother of the land' followed by the caretaker of the land Led by the water buffalo herder followed by the helper of the buffalo Led by her burake playing the small drum sounding the drum with the snakeskin head
US.COMMENTAIRE: These persons, to bunga' lalan, are 'those who open the way'. 'Mother of the Land' is a ceremonial specialist who ritually plants the rice at the start of the agricultural cycle (Coville 2003). Bunga' Lalan may also refer to the Pleiades. Tandilo ula' ('snake') refers to the garatung, a small, snakeskin-pellet drum of the to burake officiant; tandilo rante (from rante 'big ceremonial field') 'field zither' referring to 'gong'.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Ne' Lumbaa playing his garatung pellet drum, bua' kasalle, Bamba (Deri), 1993.

US.STROPHE:
The path she takes is no path
she travels a way that is no way
A rainbow is her path
lightning is her route
bolt of lightning where she crosses
US.COMMENTAIRE: The last triad is often sung by the singers. See badong from Rantetayo area, lines 36-37. - 132. Mian: fast

US.STROPHE:
She crosses on a waning moon
she goes over on a declining moon
US.COMMENTAIRE: Sampe bulan: waning moon. Bulan sampe barani: every fifteen days.

US.STROPHE:
She passes over an impenetrable mountain
she goes by way of a mountain without hair
land without holes

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Landscape from the tallu kalo'na area, Rindingallo district, 2005.

US.STROPHE:
She arrives at the gate of the lords
the entrance of the kings
village of the lordly ones
here at the gate of Randanan
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 139. Datu: title of Austronesian nobility. In the Toraja language, often refers to a female divinity. - 140. Karaeng: Makassar noble title. The Makassar are the neighbors of the Toraja in the southern part of South Sulawesi. - 142. Randanan is the village of Indo' Serang, the deceased woman, and the place of utterance.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Village at the top of a hill, Baruppu', 1993.

US.STROPHE:
143 A truly beautiful village here
a wonderful house indeed
Village created by the masters
built by the divine spirits
owned by the Creator
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 145. Puang: god, deity, lord, master, owner. A title given to aristocratic families in the south of Tana Toraja. - 146. Dewata or deata: divinity, deity, vital energy, divine spirits, life spirits. The deata are the deified ancestors of the rising sun, whereas to matua ('the old') are the ancestors of the setting sun (Nooy-Palm 1979). - 147. The smith is the title of one of the gods, the Old Gold (Puang Matua), who creates a great number of elements by forging them (Zerner 1981).

US.STROPHE:
Village that is broad and high
its terraces sheltering
its shelter peaceful

Village facing upward
shaded from the sun
peaceful everywhere
US.COMMENTAIRE: Upstream (rekke), abode of the divinities, has more prestige than downstream (sau'), which is the place of the deceased, of ancestors, where the nobles only on the way to their divinisation.

US.STROPHE:
The gate of Rongkong protects
Pantilang also shelters
Goa is visited above
US.COMMENTAIRE: Three directions are suggested: North, East, and South. North is Rongkong (in the Luwu' district). Pantilang is southeast of Rantepao. Goa, an old Makassar kingdom, is in the south (close to the present-day Makassar).

US.STROPHE:
The earth yellow like gold beads
the roof of the house is tall
A place for building a house
a place that's lively and prosperous
an exceptional village

The place where she is married
where she is wedded
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 162. Literally, 'agreement on the penalty [to pay in case of separating]. Rampanan kapa' refers to the Toraja wedding agreement. Rampan 'to go to, to go down to' and kapa' '1) cotton 2) fine, penalty'. The penalty or fine has to be paid by the marriage partner responsible for dissolving the marriage bond. Usually, where there is a separation, the one who is responsible has to give one or more buffaloes to his or her partner. The fine varies according to social level. Before the arrival of Christianity, Toraja marriage was not an important feast. There was often no feast at all (Nooy-Palm 1986:114). - 163. Kaso: 'rafter'. The part of the house which is mentioned in the poem is a metaphor for sexual union. Laths lay on supports. Metaphor that links architecture to marriage.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Kaso 'rafter'. The part of the house which is mentioned in the poem is a metaphor for sexual union. Laths lay on supports.

US.STROPHE:
A well-matched marriage
with someone not an outsider
Their adz united
the blade the same
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 165. Literally, 'to a different being, to another one'.

US.STROPHE:
Uniting their ritual deeds
joining together their ritual speech
in accordance with their glory

Uniting the rites of the fine-toothed comb
joining the ricefields
in accordance with the rites of the fragrant grasses
US.COMMENTAIRE: Daenan 'continent, universe, earth'.

US.STROPHE:
Uniting their riches
joining their ricefields
in accordance with their glory

Uniting the seas
joining the rivers
combining the deep ponds
US.COMMENTAIRE: This triad suggests the union of noble ricefields; sexual intercourse is another interpretation suggested by one informant.

US.STROPHE:
Someone with two rows of ricefields
three mouths of rivers
six divine channels

She divides things in small pieces
they consider her a childless woman
US.COMMENTAIRE: Three possible meanings:1) The farmers come to check their paddy fields to monitor the rice growth, just as barren women are visited; 2) Another informant explains that this couple shares little, like barren women who are reputed to be stingy; 3) If everybody get small pieces, she will be considered a childless woman, because if she has no child, she can afford to be a social person.

US.STROPHE:
The marriage is built
the union takes place
Swayed by words that are smooth
held by words not twisting and turning
along with beautiful words
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 185. Literally, 'agreement on the penalty [to pay in case of separating]. Rampanan kapa' refers to the Toraja wedding agreement. Rampan 'to go to, to go down to' and kapa' '1) cotton; 2) fine, penalty'. The penalty or fine has to be paid by the marriage partner responsible for dissolving the marriage bond. Usually, in the case of separation, the one who is responsible has to give one or more buffaloes to his or her partner. The fine varies according to social level. (Nooy-Palm 1986, The Sa'dan Toraja, Nijhoff:114.) - 186. Metaphor for sexual union - 187. Literally 'by oily words'

MEDIA.LEGENDE: A couple, Pa' Kila and his wife, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
They forge a necklace
in iron they shape a kris
From them appear golden sprouts
appear golden beads
US.COMMENTAIRE: In a myth of creation, the old God (Puang Matua) makes his eight children by forging them from gold (Zerner 1981, 'Signs of the Spirits, Signature of the Smith: Iron Forging in Tana Toraja'. Indonesia 31: 94; Veen 1965, The Merok Feast of the Sa'dan Toraja, Nijhoff: 88-89). From their sexual union, children are born. The golden necklace refers to girls and the kris to boys. The kris is a valuable Malay dagger with a sinuous blade, ornamented with a vein, held to possess magic powers.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: A man holding a valuable kris, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
Growing held in the lap of ritual deeds
thriving supported by ritual speech
cradled by the ancestral model

MEDIA.LEGENDE: A mother with her two daughters, Saluputti district, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
Growing in the lap of the rites of the fine-toothed comb
thriving supported by the rites of cleansing
cradled by the fragrant ceremonial grass

She goes and gets married
to the rising sun and to the setting sun
upriver to the headwaters
to the middle of the village
US.COMMENTAIRE: Kinships generally go in five directions: rising sun, setting sun, upriver, downriver and village center.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Rindingallo district, on the road to Awan, upriver, 2005.

US.STROPHE:
Her roots cross the sea
and spread to the corners
her roots cross the sea
Is there an sea they cannot cross?
a river mouth that can be passed?
Here are her golden descendents

She turns it over in her mind
she considers it fully
she thinks deeply
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 210. Ba'tang 'stomach, heart, thought'. Baliang and bibi' mean to turn over.

US.STROPHE:
Skillfully holding the rites of the fine-toothed comb
carrying out the rites of cleansing
She who speaks with the drum
and converses with the gong
exchanging opinions with each other
US.COMMENTAIRE: Gong and drum are metaphors for to minaa officiants; often, a person goes to a to minaa to ask a question, to ask advice or to look for his faults through stick divination (bilang-bilang).

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Two to minaa speaking on the rice barn, Lempopoton, 2005.

US.STROPHE:
She begins to hold the rites of the fine-toothed comb
carry out the rites of cleansing
the rites for plowing the land

Then the next day early in the morning the sun is rising in the sky it is getting very hot
She watches the good omens of the birds she interprets the meanings of their sounds The little bells go in front of her the quail shows the way The egret jumps from over there the hawk soars overhead
US.COMMENTAIRE: All these signs are good omens. Wild chickens promise good luck. The lale' bird announces the birth of a nice woman. The heron, a white bird, is a positive announcement. The place of bird omens in Toraja society is important and well known in the Austronesian world (see Itie van Hout, Indonesian Weaving between Heaven and Earth: Religious Implications of Bird Motifs on Textiles, Amsterdam, Royal Tropical Institut, 1999).

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Korong, Egretta garzetta, egret, from John MacKinnon and Karen Phillips, A Field Guide to the Birds of Borneo, Sumatra, Java and Bali, Oxford University Press, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
This is what mother is expecting
this is what father is expecting
they always remember

She watches the low-lying valleys
she examines the mountains
she decorates the spade with a tassle

Making the stones sleep soundly making the spring flow quietly
If there's a spring that spouts forth if she digs it with her fingers if she tramples on it
So that everywhere it is level everything is flat like the floorboards

She sows the rice seeds
their growing is prolific
Long like a horse's mane
each head with a rice-cutter

She harvests rice like a cockatoo
carrying it in a fence-like pattern
like a fence of swords
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 247. Another possible meaning: she draws out the husk of the rice like a cockatoo.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Bekak, cockatoo, in John MacKinnon and Karen Phillips, A Field Guide to the Birds of Borneo, Sumatra, Java and Bali, Oxford University Press, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
She brings it to the village
and takes it up into the hamlet
She brings it arriving at the front room
and takes it up into the house
US.COMMENTAIRE: Sondong: northern room of a house

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Sheaf of rice, in a ricefield, 2005.

US.STROPHE:
Decorating the room
extension of the kitchen
The surplus she eats
the extra from what she puts in the cooking pot

She brings it to the market
and takes it to the gathering place
Old coins are handed over
currency of the people of Bone is given
US.COMMENTAIRE: 260. Money is referred to as pising-pising or pisik-pisik 'climbing plant'.

US.STROPHE:
She returns home, her purse filled
and her box of coins overflowing
US.COMMENTAIRE: Sepu', betel bag

US.STROPHE:
With it she buys ricefields
with it she buys water buffalo
She adds that which is long
and ties that which is far-reaching
this way extending her fame

Again she holds the rites of the fine-toothed comb
and she does the rites of cleansing
the combing rites of the ricefields

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Ne' Lumbaa looking at the chicken entrails offered to deities, Lempopoton, 2005.

US.STROPHE:
She watches the good omens of the birds she interprets the meanings of their sounds
The little bells go in front of her the quail shows the way
The egret jumps from over there the hawk soars overhead
Cheeps right and left the quail supports her back
US.COMMENTAIRE: Cheeping is a good omen About this, Ne' Lumbaa said in 2005: 'Batuananna dipamelo. Melo oninna. Misa bangsia ri sanganna tu to. Misa ri to padi buda kadanna. Susi to male mati', denni ke tu mati' manuk manuk ke to mai, tae' dikita, disanga lale', susi bitti'. Misa ia manuk manuk na garaga Puang matua ia kumua masuli' ditiro disanga lale'. 'Because it is nice. It is a nice sound. It is called that. It's like the rice that has a lot of words. Like if we come, then someone pass by, and a bird flies, we can't see it, we call it lale'. Old God made a bird hard to see and it is called lale'.

US.STROPHE:
The wide and flat space
and the hills in the ricefields
Where the embankments will be built
where the stone dikes will be laid out

If the ricefields have increased if the work has produced extra Place where a kind of glutinous rice dreams where a variety of red sticky rice sleeps
Forever making haystacks of rice inhabited by seeds of rice rows of rice never diminishing
The earnings of women's sales their handiwork is precisely apt
US.COMMENTAIRE: Pare datte and pare mandoti are two types of rice. The first is without hair, whereas the second has hair.

US.STROPHE:
Just now she goes down
when it is exchanged for a spotted buffalo
when it is sold for a small buffalo
US.COMMENTAIRE: - Bonga'-bonga': small buffalo used to buy rice (pangallian pare). - Lundara'-dara': female buffalo, of low value.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Taking the rice out of the rice barn, Baruppu', 1993.
Lundara'-dara', female buffalo, never having been pregnant, of low value.

US.STROPHE:
The granary, a place of gathering
next to the rice barn, a marketplace

Rice that refuses to be fooled and cannot be deceived
Just now she goes down and goes out the door
If exchanged for a young buffalo cow if sold for rice from the off-season if appears a male buffalo
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 302. Langgesa': word for a valued cloth; also, word for a young female buffalo, probably with markings like the pattern on the cloth. - 303. Pare alla': a second crop of rice, not the main crop for which rituals are performed; metaphor for small money, change. - 304. Doti londong: name of a precious cloth.

US.STROPHE:
The bolt of the door to the granary
and the door handle are buffalo horns
ornamental fabric a thing of play
The earnings of women's sales
their handiwork is precisely apt
US.COMMENTAIRE: A double meaning is possible: between the buffalo horns (tanduk tedong, patola) and cloth (patola and seleng refer to weaving and woodcarving seleng is a cross pattern). Patola also refers to a gold necklace made of three cylinders. The whole evokes the exchanges of rice and money. Wealth is evoked through weaving, buffalo and rice.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: A Toraja door in the form of buffalo pattern, pa'tedong, 1993.
Making a house door with the buffalo pa'tedong carving. Limbong, 2005.

US.COMMENTAIRE: Market and meeting are synonymous. In every area, markets take place every six days. - 315. Tokeran kollong: place where the buffalo is tight (toke' 'hang'; kollong 'neck'). Reference to the buffalo market in Rantepao.

US.STROPHE: They start off together, the bonga buffalo they all set forth, the saleko buffalo they ornaments the path, the dudung pindan buffalo they almost stumble, the todi' buffalo
US.COMMENTAIRE: Belo lalan: road ornaments. Literally: water buffalo with white spots ornamenting the road. These buffaloes add value to their owner. Buffaloes are grouped according to a scale, depending on their coat, their horns, their body, their origin, also the place of their curl. According to Ne' Lumbaa (p.c.), there are two classes: one created by God, and the other a human creation. In the first class: 1) Bonga, Saleko (both albino), Doti (spotted coat, with white on the head and back), Lotong boko' ('black back'); 2) Todi', Dudung pindan (white spot on the head); 3) Pudu', Samara 4) Sambao' (gray). In the second: 1) Balian (cross-breed, known for his horns, one testicle, slow and effeminate; 2) Lundara'-dara': young female never having been pregnant; 3) Bonga'-bonga': small buffalo to buy rice.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Todi', black buffalo with white forehead, Class 2.

US.COMMENTAIRE: The strophe refers to the simbuang batu, the menhir erected on the field of menhirs (rante) for a deceased of high social status. During the death ritual, buffaloes are tied to one of the menhirs and sacrificed. Each menhir erected indicates that a funeral of the highest level has been performed, one at which at least twenty-four buffaloes were killed.

This tree is called simbuang layuk. During the first part of the funeral, buffalo horns will be hung on it, along with pig jaws and chicken feathers. This tree represents the link between sky and earth, a gift from humans to deities, which is thought to help the subsequent transformation from death to life, from meat to fertile shoots. Cf. Samparan simbong lines 400-408.

US.COMMENTAIRE: - 441. lakke-lakkean or lakkean sura' (sura' 'carved'): high platform on which the deceased is placed during the funeral. This type of tower has its counterpart in the highest rising sun ritual (bua' kasalle) where the tumbang stays for several nights. About line 442, Ne' Lumbaa said to me: Iamoto doke, male tau umpanu bombongan na bai tu doke, na rok tu tedong didoke. 'People go to kill with a spear, they go with a gong and pigs to kill, they will kill the buffalo with a spear'.

Reference to the debts engaged, which are compared to animal fat. Images of hanging often appear in Toraja poetry: hanging house, hanging drum referring to the myth of Tamboro Langi', a celestial being coming down from the sky, and living in a house hanging between sky and earth. Bua uran: 'rain of fruit' or 'rain of stones', hailstorm, image of the meat swaying in the wind, or the pieces of meat cut up and thrown from the platform. - 451. With regard to this line, Ne' Lumbaa said in 2005: 'It is the meat that is shared, shared upwards, downstream, from the platform; it is given to the officiants and to the to makaka nobles.'

US.STROPHE: She selects 'the handle of the comb' she selects 'the cutting of the sunshade' she selects 'the frontpiece of the house'' she selects 'the carving of the bamboo' she selects 'the banner descended from the sky' she selects 'the spearing of the water buffalo' she selects 'the planting of the bua' celebration'
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 496. Purification rite through a chicken offering in the house. - 497. Rite of the sunshade at the rice barn, with pig and chicken offerings. - 498. House ritual. Para: outward-slanting upper part of the front and rear gable, rising in a triangle to the roof ridge. The para has two holes, left and right, through which the ba' pass, supporting its base (Kis-Jovak et al. 1988: 129). - 499. Ritual with carved bamboo that will constitute the beginning of a ladder. During this ritual small figures are carved on bamboos. Ritual specialists make pig sacrifices and put out offerings (piong). - 500. Ritual of the trident mast (bate) to which cloths and swords will be attached. Bate manurun takes place at the maro. Trident masts (bate) with ceremonial cloths and swords are planted on the ceremonial field. - 501. Merok ritual where a buffalo is killed with a spear. - 502. Bua' is the highest rising sun ritual.

US.STROPHE: When the moon is full, the ritual is complete when the moon is dark, they do the ritual in front doing it once every three nights It's as though the lords were astonished as if the nobles were amazed and the child of the owner of the land She gives them half of a jackfruit and half of a durian fruit is sent And a knife along with a spoon made from urio wood
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 503. Last part of the bua' sang rapu (or bua' kasalle) ritual. It takes place in a large field in the east known as kala'paran, from la'pa' 'free', at the east of the house. - 504. First part of bua' ritual. In 1921, an ethnographer wrote: 'After three nights of drumming and singing, they wait one month. After one month, they play the drum and sing again for three nights. Then they again wait one month. This happens three times. After the third month, begins the last step of the ceremony'. Translation from the Dutch from J. Kruijt 1921: 168.

Banu' karurungan: to have a heart as hard as a trunk, metaphor for old age. The bark of the tree is marked by small black spots like the skin of elderly persons. -537. Longa: overhanging sections of the roof at each end of the house, going up towards the sky.

US.COMMENTAIRE: The Toraja thought that death was caused by a fault; therefore to minaa are invited to see and judge the illness of the deceased. They go up to the house to look for the fault, using a leaf (lidi) that they cut (rebong) to decide the source of a problem. This ritual was called rebongan didi. According to Ne' Lumbaa, this ritual probably originated from Kesu', a village close to Rantepao. Bangkudu', also a name of a place, is synonymous with Kesu'.

US.COMMENTAIRE: - 563. Literally 'a part of the road is over'. The to minaa say: 'Let's do 'uh' now' (ma'umoki totemo). - 567. Every deceased not yet celebrated by the death ritual is considered as simply ill and, accordingly, is given food and drink. - 569. Bilang: to count, to say. Sapean tabang is the literary expression that refers to maro ritual, where the cordyline plant is used for curing. According to Ne' Lumbaa, the line indicates that around the village the rising sun ritual can still occur because the death ritual has not yet begun. - 570. To diponene': ma'nene' ritual is a rite for the ancestors when people clean the graves. This is a ritual that takes place between setting sun and rising sun rituals.

US.COMMENTAIRE: - 572. 'Golden shoot': children of the deceased. - 574. The provisions or supplies, that is to say buffalo, songs and all that the deceased will take with him for his journey.

US.STROPHE:
Successful they return holding the rope of the buffalo every of them will hold the nose string they make a collective decision
Will there be only just one water buffalo? or rather will there be three? or, mourning ritual that reaches higher?
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 577. Children bring one or several buffaloes. - 578. Tengko situru': two ploughs, two swings in the same direction. Refers to the agreements made among family members concerning the number of animals to be killed before the death ritual. - 579-581. Refers to several types of death ritual from the tallu kalo'na region. Baturondonni (or dirondon) 'fallen' refers to a funeral performed over three nights with three buffaloes; barata kendek (or dirapa'i) refers to a funeral where seven to nine buffaloes are sacrificed. The highest funeral ritual (sapu randanan) is suggested in line 583 through the expression dipuli dua, that indicates the sacrifice of two buffaloes dying at the same time as the deceased.

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: Day 1: two buffalos die with the deceased

US.STROPHE:
But good fortune comes to Indo' Seran
she is given two buffalo to cleanse the death
mourning ritual of the western side
US.COMMENTAIRE: The opening of the death ritual begins with the killing of two buffaloes (ma'puli dua) regarded as dying with the deceased. The souls of the buffaloes will accompany the deceased on his journey. The meat of these buffaloes cannot be eaten by the close family. These sacrifices mark the beginning of the fasting. Puli 'to die at the same time', sarrin 'to make a pile and to sweep it' (Koubi 1982: 63). In fact, three shadows of the deceased will leave, but not at the same time.

US.STROPHE:
Now he stands
The drum is beaten in the house with the upturned roof the drum is tapped in the heart of the house with the rhythm of a limping buffalo
It's called the sorrow of the many the lament is heard widely in the house with the upturned roof
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 586. Longa: overhanging sections of the roof at each end of the house. - 585. With reference to the drum: during the first part of the death ritual, before any animals are killed, there is a drum rhythm that first announces the death. The double-headed drum, gandang, is taken up into the house, in the direction of the setting sun. Only one head is beaten, by a relative, three times, with varying rhythms. The first two, digento tedong, 'lame buffalo' refer to the illness of the deceased; the last one 'to be dead' indicates the real death.

US.STROPHE: - 592 The counterpart of the buffalo is strangled
US.COMMENTAIRE: The widow (to balu) strangles a chicken (bali tedong 'partner of the buffalo'). She places it in the ashes of the kitchen. Line 583 says that prior to that, two buffaloes die together to represent and accompany the deceased in his journey.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: The widow strangles a chicken. Ne' Sulo's death ritual, 2000.

US.STROPHE: Opening the decorated basket untying the filled hamper She is completely decorated each one is made complete full of perfumed smells with fragrant grasses Going under the house enter the bua' With all the people come into the feast
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 602. Baka disura': decorated basket which can hold either vegetables or cloth, or other things. The three strophes refer to the sitting position of the embalmed deceased. Shortly after his death, after having being bathed in a mixture of fragrant herbs, the deceased is seated in the central room, facing the north, for three days. - 608. Ma'pasulluk: in the highest funerals, to make a buffalo enter under the house, one day before the other buffaloes (after Veen and Tammu,1972). All the passages that may refer to the bua' kasalle ritual (as opposed to the death ritual) indicate that the deceased is dressed in his best clothes, as in the highest rising sun ceremony bua'. The guests enter the living courtyard.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: The deceased, Ne'Sulo, with his head facing downstream, 2000. The sisarean is a wooden structure against the wall where the clothes of the deceased are hung.

US.COMMENTAIRE: - 614. Doti langi': 'spots of heaven', cross motifs. Small bamboo shelter built at the northwest corner of the house during the first ceremony. Buffalo hearts taken by the people fasting (to marao') will be placed there. - 615. Tombi: 'banner'. Three banners (tombi sikatok 'erected and inclined backward') are placed at three points, in the courtyard, and south and north of the village, as a sign of bereavement. They will be brought on to the ceremonial field. - 616. Simbuang layuk: sacrificial stake formed by the high buangin tree (Casuarina equisetifolia) planted in front of the house where a dog, a chicken, and a buffalo are hanged and killed. South of Rantepao, it is taken from an areca palm.

US.COMMENTAIRE: - 630. Can we only perform the highest rituals? - 631. Ritual for high noblemen. - 633. May refer to the kakarun invocation by the to minaa who call the ancestors next to the fire at night. Leaves are metaphors for words. The to minaa asks if the ritual speech should be stopped.

US.STROPHE: What does our Mother say? Let us lie down and rest enter the stone of Maulu The next day it is divided like langsat as provision for the journey in the place for drying padi
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 634. In this region, the leaders are called Ambe' 'Father' or Indo' 'Mother'. - 636. Maulu is the name of both a place and a river that flows towards the southeast, to Saluputti district. Another version of this line by Ne' Lumbaa: tama batunna bongi 'comes the stone of the night'.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Langsat fruits, metaphor for the meat in the death ritual.

US.COMMENTAIRE: - 642. Literally, 'faces are cool'. - 643. Sacrifice of a pig, the meat of which will be shared by fasting people (to marao'). Another possible meaning according to S. Sandarupa: the young rice not yet ripe is given to the fasting people to eat. - 644- 45. The fasting people (to ma'simbolong, to marao', to ma' pemali) must wear a black cloth or black hat. Simbolong and lokkon, synonymous, refer to an old type of hairbun.

US.STROPHE: The next day in the morning The two leave together stepping on the rung of the ladder the descendents of Lamba' Langi' They reach for the end of the way the grandchildren of Pangngatta of Rura They return home together without bumping into anything accompanying the scarlet shuttle the descendents of Lamba' Langi' arrive

The ritual presentation of the betel chew is performed by the family, by 'those who follow the taboos' (to ma'pemali). The betel chew is made from several ingredients: betel leaf (Piper betel, daun bolu), betel fruit (bolu bua'), areca nut (Areca catechu; toraja kalosi), and lime, the white powder (kapu').

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: Day 3: the ceremonial mast, the liquids of the deceased

US.STROPHE: The next day in the morning the reversed banner is raised along with the left-handed tombi cloth the three of them together
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 730. Bandera: trident mast with a long white cloth, on which are hung various objects associated with the deceased (if a man: bird feather bulu dassi, betel bag, umbrella). The mast, at this part of the ritual, is first planted in the courtyard then untied at the end of the day. In the south, it is also called bate lepong 'round mast, or round flag' perhaps because in earlier times a human head was hung on it (Tsintjilonis 2000: 46). One or several years later, this mast will be reversed (dibalikan batenna) with the bate deata or bate dirangga towards the rising sun during the maro ritual.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Ceremonial mast (bandera) erected in the courtyard for the deceased Ne' Sulo, To' Barana' village, 2000.

US.STROPHE:

The one who wraps arrives

US.COMMENTAIRE: - 771. This refers to two rites performed during the first death ritual by the one who wraps the dead body. Ma'pasusu (susu 'breast, milk'): to collect the liquids of the body (borro), to dry it. A system of pipes links the coffin to the earth through a hole in the floor of the house. After that, a buffalo and a pig are sacrificed; their meat is cooked (ma'parepe') and given to those who are fasting. These rituals announce the end of the first death rite.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: VIDEO: The to mebalun collect the liquids, Ne' Sulo's funeral, 2000.

US.STROPHE:
She sleeps in her decorated ship

US.COMMENTAIRE: - 773. Erong: old wooden coffin, carved in the shape of a ship or a house, reserved for nobility. Dierong: carved with the erong pattern (Veen 1972). - 775. Kundala-dala: 1) Bamboo sign signifying 'No entrance'; 2) Pieces of bamboo laid down to indicate the number of buffaloes to be killed.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: In the house, during the first funeral, the deceased lies with his head downstream, whereas the widow sleeps upriver, To Barana', 2000.

US.STROPHE:

US.COMMENTAIRE: - 777. In the maro ritual, to tumbang and to malangi' are the one who go into trance. Here, the strophe refers to the dead in his coffin, hidden by the cloth until the second part of the death ritual. The mosquito net refers in fact to a simple cloth sometimes maa' cloths simply referring to a symbolic coffin where the dead remains between the first and second parts of the death ritual. - 778. Dusen-dusen refers to the cloths around the body. - 780. Ba'teng: 1) stomach; 2) heart, thought. Lollo': liquid, refers to an overripe fruit oozing juice.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: In the house, at Randanan, Rindingallo district, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
The next day in the morning

US.COMMENTAIRE: Ma'pasusu: from susu 'breast, milk', to collect the liquids of the body (borro), to dry it. A system of pipes links the coffin to the earth through a hole in the floor of the house. After that, a buffalo and a pig are sacrificed; their meat is cooked (ma'parepe') and given to those who are fasting. These rituals announce the end of the first death rite.

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: A few days after, the blackening of the cloths

US.STROPHE:
The next day is the day of blackening they enter the state of mourning they make it known to everyone
Then it is placed again the ancestral model the base of the bobbin is taken up
From Rura to Sangngalla' from Duri to Tikala the ancestral model has arrived
US.COMMENTAIRE: The ritual of blackening the clothes takes place three days after the first funeral. The ones who were fasting can now eat again. - 785. Barata: 1) bereavement; 2) mourning clothes; 3) to make one's clothes black for mourning; 4) headhunting (dibarata tau 'to look for a human head').

US.STROPHE: It makes the spirit of the dead happy it pleases the one who will become deata it fills the ancestral model
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 793. Human beings have a 'life-spirit' deata, in their bodies. This is the source of vitality. It can leave the body during sleep or illness. It can take the temporary shape of an animal. At the beginning of a funeral, this life-spirit becomes independent and changes into a bombo 'black shadow'. After its long journey toward the place of ancestors, and the ma'nene' ritual, it will be again be called deata (Tsintjilonis 2000: 34). According to S. Sandarupa, the bombo may be considered to be the spirit of the dead. Frightening, it is associated with darkness. It is a very active agent. The funeral ritual leads this spirit step by step from one place to another, to the next world; at the end, it will become a god (to membali puang). Line 793 may sound like popa'inan which could mean 'it makes a place for the spirit of the dead', which does not in fact make any real sense following what has gone before. Usually popaiman is paired with sende.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Women mourning the deceased between the two death rituals.

US.STROPHE:

with all of its branches

covering with mud

they go the feeding ritual
then they call that...

US.STROPHE:
Sunhats are already spread far and the blackened headband and the string of bamboo the ring of mourning
They separate from piece of banana the building of the house
They separate from the soaked corn the construction of homes
US.COMMENTAIRE: They stop the fast and can then pass to the side of the rising sun rituals.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Indo' Serang widow, with her mourning scarf, Randanan, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
The sun hits it and makes it glitter ornamented by the sun
They go changing the light they leave carrying torches
Maybe the one they are looking for
US.COMMENTAIRE: 991. Buffaloes and pigs

US.STROPHE:
will just come home to her dearly beloved
Will come home to embank the sea will check the estuary will dam up the wide lake
Those are the provisions for the journey that she will give back dearly beloved
US.COMMENTAIRE: Tasik, minanga and liku are metaphors for ricefields.

US.STROPHE:
She goes by way of the river
she goes by way of the Lombu River

She arrives down there at the gate of To' Dama'
the place where she stops to chew betel
she sits down reddening her mouth
the tobacco wads in rows of three
US.COMMENTAIRE: To' Dama' is the toponym for Tondok Litak. - 1004. Kaluang (or sugigi): tobacco already sucked. Often the Toraja suck the tobacco after or before chewing betel. They put some tobacco on their lips before chewing.

US.STROPHE:
She glances back, but it's not her home
she looks, but it's not her house
She glances back in tears
she looks, full of sorrow
US.COMMENTAIRE: A song from this strophe is performed by the badong in Rantetayo village, number 17-20.

US.STROPHE:
The next day in the morning she goes stepping with her feet she goes swinging her arms
She travels along the Bakkun River she takes the Karangan River as her route she goes by way of the stone bridge
she arrives at Tokkonan Dido'
US.COMMENTAIRE: The Bakkun river is located close to Riu. Karangan 'gravel'. The last line is literally 'Field of the blackbird perch', meaning a place without people.

US.STROPHE:
comes to the flat meeting place
where she sits and chews betel
the tobacco wads in rows of three

She glances back, but it's not her home
she looks but it's not her house
She glances back in tears
looks, full of sorrow

She travels along Karrang Bulu
she takes the Balulang mountain as her route
Goes through Tokkonan Dido'
Crosses the Malangngo' river
US.COMMENTAIRE: The Malangngo' river flows towards the south. Karrang: 1) frightening; 2) karrang bulu: shoot without leaves but with hairs that grows up stones or trees

US.STROPHE: Arrives at rante Menduruk sits and chews betel She sits down reddening her mouth the tobacco wads in rows of three

She glances back, but it's not her home
she looks but it's not her house
She glances back in tears
she looks, full of sorrow
She travels along Batu Lelleng
she goes through Tombonan Batu
she arrives at the fringed banyan tree
At the banyan that's weeping at the lamba' tree that's fallen the sandalwood full of sorrow
US.COMMENTAIRE: Spirits live in banyan trees (Veen 1966, The Sa'dan Toradja Chant for the Deceased, Nijhoff: 58). Sandalwood, a tree of great value, (Santalum album) is planted in front of the house towards the rising sun during the bua' kasalle ritual.

US.STROPHE:
The next day in the morning
she goes stepping with her feet
she goes swinging her arms
Down there are slopes leaning on each other
Down there are valleys facing each other

Going along the steep edges
a path without hardship
She passes many villages
further and further downriver
houses clustered together

They say, the people of Duri from the lips of the people of Enrekang:
'So it is that tomorrow when she passes from up there I call but she doesn't talk I speak but she doesn't say anything
Only the palm of her foot speaks her heel says something her foot talks'
US.COMMENTAIRE: Duri and Enrenkang, places located in the south of Toraja country. These toponyms indicate that the soul goes downstream.

US.STROPHE:
'Sobbing behind the strands of her hair
her movements full of sorrow
but she is no longer visible'

The ship has vanished
it comes and appears again
A ship wandering
going down to Mundan
The border of Larombo the boundary of Paredean near Pantara Gallang
Poor thing she is only a skeleton a whetstone that's been discarded
US.COMMENTAIRE: All these places are located in the south, around Enrekang.

US.STROPHE:
So that we crow like roosters so that we make sounds like birds cackle as a rattlesnake
it's not the chicken of Lapande' it's not the rooster of Pongtulang Didi'
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 1074. Arai: kind of snake with a chicken's head (Waterson 1989, 'Hornbill, Naga and Cock in Sa'dan Toraja Woodcarving Motifs'. Archipel 38: 53-73). Lapande' and Tulangdidi are synonyms. The entire passage refers to the myth of the young girl Tulangdidi who was brought back to life by the singing of a rooster. This rooster, who fulfilled the wishes of the girl, went to the sky with Tulangdidi and they became divinities. Human beings look toward the sky because these two influence sowing (Koubi 1982: 377).

MEDIA.LEGENDE: The arae is sculpted on some noble houses.

US.STROPHE:
She wakes up but it's not her face she appears but it's not her likeness it is not a visible body
Poor thing she is only a skeleton like a knife sharpener that is useless
She has become the tool of the lords the knife sharpener of the gods spread all over
Beginning to hide inside the tube of bamboo in the space between the nodes of bamboo The design that's close together in the form of an old doti cloth
US.COMMENTAIRE: In the last line, doti refers to a wooden pattern or may refer to a spell placed on human or animals. Doti matua was a shape engraved on erong, burial place.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Wooden pattern on old coffins erong, Ke'te' Kesu', 2005.

US.STROPHE:
Shifting toward the western side where the sun disappears
Standing like a coconut tree there will be standing like a palm tree standing and watching downwards
Waiting for the sheltering leaf
US.COMMENTAIRE: One of the two to minaa, Ne' Sulo, comments (in 1993) on this strophe: 'Now, she becomes a divinity' (mendeata). During a death ritual, the buffalo is tied to the sugar palm. The trunk is called simbuang induk. The souls of the deceased and the buffaloes that accompany him reach the sky by going up this trunk.

US.STROPHE:
Standing like a coconut tree there
will be standing like a palm tree
US.COMMENTAIRE: Performed at the end of the death ritual, this strophe is sung in a badong round dance, in a very lively way similar to the bugi' song of the rising sun ritual. The music here resembles the mood of a rising sun ritual because the soul is considered to become a divinity by its ascent to the sky. Sung at the death ritual of a leader in Bokko, at Tumbang Datu, Randan Batu region, Rantepao plain, 1993.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Sugar palm tree [Arenga Pinnata], induk. The ladder is used for collecting the palm wine that never dries up.

US.STROPHE:
He will ascend to heaven
she will make her home up there
her words from up there
the words that she says

Why is it me who you talk about? who you reach for and remember? Keep in your hearts the essence of this lament
It has been said: Go back down all you who are surrounding like waves crashing on the shore

MEDIA.LEGENDE: The badong narrative sung as a badong round dance, Penduan Ra'ba', 2001.

US.STROPHE:
It's blessings she gives us and well-being she offers us
We all have the string we all wear a nose ring
we all turn upwards
The end
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 1107. Ra'pak-ra'pak: plant that grows in stony places. This plant is buried with the afterbirth of children at the east of the house; metaphor for rain. The deceased becomes an ancestor transformed into a constellation and responsible for the seasons. Other texts (Veen 1966, The Sa'dan Toradja Chant for the Deceased, Nijhoff: 36), relate how the soul goes to the sky, becomes a star and helps humans to sow rice. - 1110. Kale'ke': a ring in the nose of the buffalo through which a rope is passed. The strophe suggests that humans are here with their buffaloes, they look upward as a sign that they may go to sacrifice buffaloes for their ancestors, as a gift from humans to the deceased.

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: 1. Going by way of palm-tree decorated ladder

US.STROPHE: Going by way of palm-tree decorated ladder
US.COMMENTAIRE: Recorded in 1993, during the death ritual of a leader of Bokko, in Tumbang Datu, Randan Batu region, Rantepao plain. This death ritual was performed for five nights according to the old ritual style. The excerpt transcribed here was translated with the help of Y. K. Galla', also called Ne' Yessi (Tumbang Datu). - 1. The two lines here refer to 'Mellao ma'eran pusuk, ke'de' ma'tete' batara'.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Pusuk leaves on a house, after a rising sun ritual.

US.STROPHE:
Don't you people know?
when people from far away sense it

People from far away sense it
those from distant lands feel it
US.COMMENTAIRE: Pebau' and uduk:'to kiss', to 'sniff or smell' and by extension 'sense, learn, know a little' (Veen and Tammu 1972).

US.STROPHE:
Our wide-leafed tree is felled
our tall tree is fallen

Felled in the heavens
fallen across the heavens

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: 10. Going down with his ritual deeds

US.STROPHE: Going down with his ritual deeds
US.COMMENTAIRE: The strophe is Mellao sola alukna, ke'de' sola pemalinna ('Going with his ritual deeds, departing with his prohibitions'). Here, only the first line of the strophe is sung. Other lines are sung between this first line (10) and the second line (21).

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Death ritual lasting five nights, Bokko, 27 September 1993.

US.STROPHE:
Look at this true man
going down with his ritual deeds
US.COMMENTAIRE: This first line is now forbidden when the deceased is Christian. It represents the basis of social stratification within the Toraja culture.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Death ritual lasting five nights, Bokko, 27 September 1993. The body is put down.

US.STROPHE:
Going down with his ritual deeds
departing with his prohibitions
US.COMMENTAIRE: Aluk ('law', 'ritual') and pemali ('taboo') are at the core of the old Toraja religion.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Death ritual lasting five nights, Bokko, 27 September 1993. The body is put down.

US.STROPHE:
Dreaming in the carved boat
sleeping in the golden bamboo tube
US.COMMENTAIRE: The metaphor of the boat is often used to signify the coffin. The old coffin, erong, in the shape of a rice mortar, rectangular, may be similar to the shape of a boat.

US.STROPHE:
Dreaming with his ritual deeds
sleeping with his prohibitions

Sleeping with his ritual deeds
together with his prohibitions
Departing with the prohibitions

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Death ritual lasting five nights, Bokko, September 1993.

US.STROPHE:
Poor thing, our ancestor up there
Going down with his ritual deeds
US.COMMENTAIRE: The descent evoked here refers to the divine birth of the deceased, who came down from the sky.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Death ritual lasting five nights, Bokko, 27 September 1993.

US.STROPHE: Going by way of a palm tree ladder the bua' stone as a bridge
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 25. Patangdo (or parangka) refers to the stone planted with the sandalwood in front of the house in the bua' kasalle ceremony, on the rising sun side. Plants that help to cure, such as the cordyline, are put on this stone. According to tradition, the first bua' ceremony was performed in the sky (Veen 1966, The Sa'dan Toradja Chant for the Deceased, Nijhoff: 20). The passage as a whole refers to the beginning of the hagiographic ossoran badong.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: The vegetal ornaments, indicators of rising sun rituals, are placed on the house during the bua' kasalle ceremony, Deri, May 1993.

US.STROPHE:
Indeed it is different for those who are different
those who are created by the gods

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Death ritual lasting five nights, Bokko, September 1993.

US.STROPHE:
Those whose births are extraordinary
whose fashioning was exceptional
those who were created in the heavens
generated in the skies
US.COMMENTAIRE: Lalleu: from lan 'inside'. Literally 'a human being born into the sky'

US.STROPHE:
Those who were made in the moon
and engendered in the stars
indeed this is heredity
certainly ever since the beginning

Is he made incorrectly?
did his fashioning go awry?
A child was fashioned
and buffalo milk boiled for him
US.COMMENTAIRE: Rara': necklace consisting of three wooden cylinders covered in gold, metaphor for high class women (Nooy-Palm 1969, 'Dress and Adornment of the Sa'dan Toradja'. Tropical Man: 173).

US.STROPHE: Attaching the ceremonial cloth
US.COMMENTAIRE: Bangla' 'new'. Tali 'cord, cloth'. The ceremonial cloth maa' is hung.

US.STROPHE: Golden necklace at the beam
US.COMMENTAIRE: Lunte: to put into movement, animate, swing (like a plant moved by the wind); luntean: eru wood that is put in the house close to the effigy (anak dara), during the bua' kasalle ritual. According to an informant, a necklace is fixed to a stalk. In death rituals lasting longer than three nights ceremonial cloths are brought with a bead necklace.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Rara', golden necklace wore by a young girl.

US.STROPHE:
Tambunan Balik Bokko
made an agreement
US.COMMENTAIRE: Tambunan, Balik and Bokko are sites where this song was recorded.

US.STROPHE:
indeed the word was true
we affirm it

they made an agreement
always we recite it

Make one speech
one direction for the plow

one direction for the plow
unity of unions
Forever a sleeping pillow

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Widow, deceased and funerary officiant, Randanan, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
Those who wear sarongs have hope
the people of Tambunan have arrived

Those who bite the iron arrive
those who cut bananas gather
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 51. Ma'kekeran bassi: to bite iron, refers to the fasting by close relatives, who eats only corn, which is hard, during the period of mourning instead of rice, which is soft. The iron is a substitute for the corn, and biting on it is gesture in case a member of the family has died when away from home and his family are unaware of it, and they should be in mourning (Veen 1966, The Sa'dan Toradja Chant for the Deceased, Nijhoff: 76). - 52. Limbong: 'pond', meaning that a lot of people are fasting for the deceased.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Two fasting people, death ritual, Bokko, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
Here in this village of sadness
the houses of the lonesome ones

MEDIA.LEGENDE: At the center of a badong round dance, Baruppu', 1993.

US.STROPHE: Tumbang Datu in Bokko Patana in Tambunan
US.COMMENTAIRE: Tumbang Datu and Patana' are the ancestors of this site.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Death ritual in Bokko, when the body is brought to the burial place, 1993.

US.STROPHE: Unwilling to move like a boundary marker

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Death ritual in Bokko, when the body is brought to the burial place, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
Tumbang Datu in Bokko
holding the word of agreement
US.COMMENTAIRE: Bokko is the name of the site where the song is sung.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Death ritual in Bokko, when the body is brought to the burial place, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
Holding the word of agreement
here in this village of mourning

MEDIA.LEGENDE: The three places, from Peta Rupabumi Indonesia, 1991.

US.STROPHE: Patana' and Tumbang Datu taking turns giving each other advice

Making one word
together holding the plow
that we always recite

MEDIA.LEGENDE: The mortuary effigy (tau-tau) is brought to the sacrificial field (rante), Bokko, 1993.

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: 67. Each one shaking and moving from their places

US.STROPHE: Each one shaking and moving from their places He is given provisions for the journey he is given food for the crossing down at the edge of the sky

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Buffaloes sacrificed on the day of the burial, Bokko, 1993.

US.STROPHE: As provisions for the journey
US.COMMENTAIRE: The deceased travel to the other world which is full of objects, meat, and words given by the living.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Sacrificed buffaloes when the body is brought to the burial place, Bokko,1993.

US.STROPHE: As sustenance for the crossing
US.COMMENTAIRE: Songs and meat are considered provisions for the long walk of the soul.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Round dance for the deceased, Baruppu', 1993.

US.STROPHE:
To all of us to all of us
Excuse me, we're going home now
This is indeed true words the mother of the Badong is going home

Our lament says
the source of our mourning song
We made it when we were still little
we composed it when we were still small

We wear headbands made of bamboo
we wear the hats of students
we don't know the river of the lament
and the channel of the mourning song

To those whom we call elder sibling
and those we call father
Come let us weave the lament
for you who are clever
US.COMMENTAIRE: The young singers admire their fathers.

US.STROPHE: Brought by the ancestors
US.COMMENTAIRE: This refers to the deceased who are already ancestors and who will welcome the new deceased.

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: Carrying the body to the grave

US.STROPHE:
He will be helped down there
he will be worshipped
US.COMMENTAIRE: This is a fast badong, quite joyful, known as Pa' Randen. Dancers jump in a lively fashion (mekondong, melatta') as if it were a bugi' dance on the side of the rising sun. Women may dance with the men in that particular badong.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Badong round dance around the dead buffaloes on the day of departure to the burial place, Bokko, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
He stands like a straight coconut
he lives like the blossomed palm

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Departure of the body for the burial place, Bokko, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
He goes down the stairway of palm
he stands up taking the sky as his bridge
he stands up taking the sky as his bridge

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Departure of the body for the burial place, Bokko, 1993.

US.STROPHE: Scattering the fruit of the tina' tree dividing the rolled up cotton
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 99. Darandang: cotton plant placed in a band around a leaf and hung for the divinities at the offering place. It is rubbed with animal blood and given as a sign of a pure heart with regard to the offering.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Departure of the body for the burial place, Bokko, 1993.

US.STROPHE: It is a happy day

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Departure of the body for the burial place, Bokko, 1993.

US.STROPHE: Arriving with his ancestors

As long as we give you the lament
with the falling of our tears
US.COMMENTAIRE: Recorded at the death ritual of Ne' Sakkung at Tapparan (Saluputti district), 2 July 1993. Ne' Sakkung is a Protestant. This is the day the body is moved from the rice barn to the ceremonial field. The name of the prompter ('he who sounds the lamentation') is Ne' Bassi (from Padang Iring). The rank of this ritual corresponds to the death ritual of the highest degree. The number of sacrifices and of singers is even higher (one hundred buffaloes, hundreds of singers). Title of the song: Pa' Baliangan. The dance has four arm impulses.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Ne' Bassi, prompter of the lament, Rantetayo, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
Our lament we call a buffalo
the mourning song is a pig
the sadness is cooked rice
US.COMMENTAIRE: Title: Pa' Porro or Pa' Paturun. Movement of the arms downward, with four impulses. The lyrics state that speech given to the deceased is equivalent to an animal gift. Song, speech, and animals all are provisions given to the deceased for his journey.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Many round dances at the same time, Tapparan,1993.

US.STROPHE:
That which we prepare as provisions for the road
and as supplies for the crossing
US.COMMENTAIRE: Title: Pa' senta-senta. The name derives from the movement of the arms, (disoyan senta). The shadow of the deceased goes on its journey downriver. It goes with provisions (songs, buffaloes) for the road, given at the death ritual.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: In the middle of the round dance, the ones who reject the spells, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
That which the lords bring
that which the ancestors make appear
US.COMMENTAIRE: Title: Pa'bonno. According to the song leader, Daut Puppung from Rantetayo, (in 2001) 'it is a badong with a discontinuous sound, with silences. The arms are down'.

US.STROPHE:
The constellation (Lemba') is hidden
vanished in the blink of an eye
up in the fringe of the sky
where the heavens are overcast
US.COMMENTAIRE: Title: Badong sang sese ('one half'). Fast, arms up, four accents. The soul or shadow of the deceased (bombo) goes for a long trip towards the firmament, on the setting sun. the firmament, sky, is the place where the soul will go, showing its noble descent.

US.STROPHE:
If you reside in heaven
heaven is a good place
a magnificent place
US.COMMENTAIRE: Strophe from the Protestant Church. Title: Badong Pa' paradan ('to stop'). 'It is not a badong where the mouths meet' (tannia badong sitammui puduk)', said the song leader, Daut Puppung, in 2001.

US.STROPHE:
Glance back just once more
turn back toward the other side
to glance back at your village
to look at your clan house
US.COMMENTAIRE: Title: Badong Pa' dondo/Pa' rantang.This line comes from the end of ossoran badong (hagiography), see in this same anthology, line 1031 and following.

US.STROPHE:
Look at the genuine man
a person made by the Creator
US.COMMENTAIRE: Badong is 'dibatingi, dikadongi' which means that every group adds another line from the two first lines; it literally signifies 'to attach sheaves of rice'. The expression 'real being', used exclusively for the nobility, is, in fact, forbidden in the Christian death ritual.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: The deceased, from the high nobility, in his red and gold coffin, 1991.

US.STROPHE:
He goes along dug up fields
he travels by way of dried up mud holes
US.COMMENTAIRE: After the recitation of the main line, each group's soloist sings a couplet and the chorus sings the last word of the line. This badong is dibatingi, dikadongi.

US.STROPHE:
Do people not see?
does nothing meet their eye?

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Lakkean tower where the body is placed during the death ritual.

US.STROPHE:
Do people not know?
has the word not spread?

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Up and left, the coffin, at Penduan Ra'ba, 2001.

US.STROPHE:
Who else is like him?
as elevated as he?

MEDIA.LEGENDE: The deceased, wrapped in his coffin, during the death ritual, 1991.

US.STROPHE: Pa' to Ulusalu
US.COMMENTAIRE: The body is carried from the rice barn to the ceremonial field. This is the badong pa'songlo 'badong for going down'.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Carrying the body from the rice barn to the ceremonial field, Tapparan, 1993.

US.STROPHE: Our mother tells us and the one who gave birth to us Let's go and weave the lament heirloom cloth (lotong boko') as ridge of roof
US.COMMENTAIRE: Title: Pa' To Bela. This is a badong from Sillanan. Lotong boko' ('black back') refers to a pattern resembling a black backed buffalo; refers also to a ceremonial cloth, white and black, imported from India.

US.STROPHE: The incline is like lightning
US.COMMENTAIRE: Badong from Pangngala'.

US.STROPHE: He goes along the rainbow
US.COMMENTAIRE: This piece is called Pa' Bas. It is a standard line throughout the area whenever the body is carried from one place to another, and in particular at the end of the death ritual when the 'shadow' goes on its journey towards the setting sun. 'He takes the rainbow as his path/the flash lightning is his way/He walked along the kindled forks' (Veen 1966, The Sa'dan Toradja Chant for the Deceased, Nijhoff: 61). This is the glorification of a wonderful being whose soul travels through atmospheric phenomena.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Funeral round dance around the body, before its departure, 1993.

US.STROPHE: The ones who cry: Ma'bating.
US.COMMENTAIRE: The deceased is carried many times during the funeral, from the house to the rice barn, from the rice barn to a ritual path, from the path to the sacrificial field, and, lastly, from this field to the burial place. When the body is moved, the mourners cry as part of the ritual. This weeping is called bating.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: To' Malolo village, Sa'dan district, 20 September 1993. To weep over the coffin before the departure to the burial place.
To' Malolo village, Sa'dan district, 20 September 1993. To weep over the coffin before the departure to the burial place.
To' Malolo village, Sa'dan district, 20 September 1993. A woman loses consciousness during the weeping.

US.STROPHE: He travels by way of dried up mud holes
US.COMMENTAIRE: A famous line usually coupled with another: Malulun rante naola/ma'ti tombang napolalan 'the plain's grass did he tread down, the pond he walked across dried up'). Various interpretations are possible: it may refer to the journey of the soul downriver, or to the death ritual itself. Pond and field could refer to the ceremonial field, full of guests.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Ceremonial field with the guests, during buffalo fights, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
Look at this genuine man
an honest person made by the Creator
He goes along dug up fields
he travels by way of dried up mud holes
US.COMMENTAIRE: This is a badong for walking badong Pa'pasonglo. It is performed when the body is carried. The first line is now forbidden by different Churches. It is a line especially reserved for the deceased from the high nobility who are considered to become ancestors. The true human is a model of a gentleman, of a brave man. Though the ritual is 'Protestant', the line is performed. See line 45 and following.

US.STROPHE:
Make yourself light
so we can carry you with our fingers
US.COMMENTAIRE: Each time the body is moved during the death ritual, the palanquin of the deceased is carried and shaken forcefully by a group of men, generally badong singers. They bring him through his ricefields.

US.STROPHE:
Look at this genuine man
a person made by the Creator
US.COMMENTAIRE: This strophe was changed by the Church. Before Christianization, the strophe was 'look at this true man, created by divinities' (tiromi tu tau tongan, tu to natampa deata). The change underlines the passage from polytheism to monotheism. The song is usually sung when the body is brought from the rice barn to his tower (lakke-lakkean) in the center of the ceremonial field (rante). Its title is Badong Masal.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Palanquin for the deceased, before going to the burial place, Tapparan, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
Whoever is like him?
who is his equal?

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Palanquin for the deceased, last day, Tapparan, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
People are carrying again
and still carrying again
getting the highest of riches
and an oasis of possessions
US.COMMENTAIRE: Title: Badong Pa' tobela, from Sillanan village.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Before going to the burial place, Tapparan, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
One who refuses to be sheltered
who won't be protected
he is the one who will be the shelter
giving shade from above
US.COMMENTAIRE: Title: Pa' Bale Bolu.

US.STROPHE:
Indeed this is the ritual of the ancestors
indeed the model of the forebears
the ritual that comes from the sky
the model that has descended

It refuses to be rained on
here in this world

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Effigies of divine ancestors, south of Rantepao.

US.STROPHE: She is given provisions for the journey
US.COMMENTAIRE: Recorded during a Protestant death ritual at Tikala (Buntu Lempong, Tikala Atas), 7 July 1993. Two deceased, a man and a woman, both Christian, received the death ritual. A group of singers from Baruppu' was invited through family links. They received one buffalo for their performance. They had no prompter. The tradition of Baruppu' singing is different from that in other places. Some lines, very few, are borrowed from the hagiography ossoran badong.

US.COMMENTAIRE: - 9. Rapu. 'The kinship structure of the Sa'dan Toraja is dominated by the marapuan, a cognatic descent group or ramage. The distinguishing character of the marapuan is its orientation towards a first ancestor. () Marapuan is a vast, inclusive structure which is involved during extremely large rituals such as the bua' kasalle feast' (Nooy-Palm 1979, The Sa'dan Toraja: A Study of Their Social Life and Religion, Nijhoff: 22). For kinship, see also Waterson 1995, 'Houses, Graves and the Limits of Kinship Groupings among the Sa'dan Toraja', Bijdragen.

US.COMMENTAIRE: Refers to Toraja emigration outside Tana Toraja and beyond Sulawesi. Emigration has been considerable since the end of the twentieth century. In some regions, half the population emigrates, often to Irian Jaya or Malaysia. Saro: 1) to look for a wage 2) wage. Saroan: mutual aid organization in a village, for ritual or agricultural work.

() Marapuan is a vast, inclusive structure which is involved during extremely large rituals such as the bua' kasalle feast' (Nooy-Palm 1979, The Sa'dan Toraja: A Study of Their Social Life and Religion, Nijhoff: 22). For more on kinship, see also Waterson 1995, 'Houses, Graves and the Limits of Kinship Groupings Among the Sa'dan Toraja'. Bijdragen tot de taal-, land- en volkenkunde 151 (2): 194-217.

US.COMMENTAIRE: 30. Metaphors of liquid linking the weeping to the river are often used in funerary poetry, and also sometimes in rising sun poetry. On the side of the setting sun (rites of death), the weeping, the river, the liquids of the deceased; on the other side, of the rising sun (rites of life): ricefield, fecundity and waterfalls.

US.COMMENTAIRE: During the death ritual, the family gives the singers 'ornaments for the mouth', that is to say, ingredients for chewing betel and cigarettes. Bolu and gambir: two ingredients for the betel chew. Bolu: young betel sprout, green and fragrant it is broken into small parts. Gatta': hard part, red. Distinct from Indian cachou, gambir, often used in Indonesia, comes from a mixture of leaves and shoots from a Rubiacee, ourouparia gambir, boiled then dried in the sun. (Solange Thierry, Le btel, Inde et Asie du sud-est, 1969: 11). The tobacco is wiped on the teeth.

tall ferns sway in the breeze
Would they sway
if not blown by the breeze?
US.COMMENTAIRE: - 69. Pakulando or paku lando: diplazium proliferum, type of big fern, possible metaphor for socially poor people (personal communication of a singer).

US.STROPHE:
Give him a chicken to make him sleep
and for us who cannot sleep
Many egrets inside
Egrets that wonder
US.COMMENTAIRE: The first couplet suggests that singers sing at night when the chickens sleep, while the second refers to the great activity by all the family members during the death ritual.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Death ritual at Bokko, going to the burial place, 1993.

US.STROPHE:
What can we do?
what's to be done?

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Carved pattern on a coffin, Ke'te' Kesu'.

US.STROPHE:
It's just the locusts that pass by
pass by reminding us
US.COMMENTAIRE: Lilling ala': Indonesian Uir-uir. Comparison between the voice and the sound of this insect, according to a singer (personal communication).

MEDIA.LEGENDE: At a burial place, Ke'te' Kesu'.

US.STROPHE:
Perhaps it is not done like that
in the style of today
US.COMMENTAIRE: Up into the house, later, twenty-five singers

US.STROPHE: Don't cross over there if the water is muddy Go into the shelter, friend, so we stay in let us go singing dondi' in the afternoon
US.COMMENTAIRE: Metaphor of the crossing river, bridge, mountain referring to the journey of the soul to the world of ancestors.

US.STROPHE: What's that river down there? that flows upwards? Go into the shelter, friend, so we stay in let us go up singing dondi' in the afternoon We are many gathered here now densely packed together
US.COMMENTAIRE: In the first couplet, reference is made to the contrast upstream/downstream, essential for Toraja space. The divinities are located upstream and to the rising sun while the ancestors and souls of the deceased are located downstream and at the setting sun.

US.STROPHE:
Don't sleep too much
that you are pursuing
don't dream
US.COMMENTAIRE: Message to the mourners who come to sleep.

US.STROPHE:
We will block the overflowing
embankment of the golden ricefield
US.COMMENTAIRE: Kondo rara': 'golden ricefield'; ceremonial cloth.

US.STROPHE:
A tree growing at the edge of the field
a tree in front of our eyes
Perhaps it's a shelter
in case we are lonely
US.COMMENTAIRE: Rante: ceremonial field for the death ritual.

US.STROPHE:
Perhaps it won't be the same any more
the way of doing it today

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Door of a burial place, Ke'te' Kesu'.

US.STROPHE:
We are quite a few now
we are all densely gathered
US.COMMENTAIRE: A la tello-tello: vocal flourishes.

US.STROPHE:
The middle of the night has already passed
the darkness is the same
The end of the village is dark
and next to the houses

So it has happened
and so it will always be
We are quite a few now
we are all densely gathered

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Burial place in a cave, Ke'te' Kesu'.

US.STROPHE:
The more the world is what the world is
