Spread your heart
unfold your friendliness
US.COMMENTAIRE: First lines recalling probably the two worlds, that of the living and that of the dead. Salu alle and ala tello-tello are vocal flourishes.

US.STROPHE:
When the sky begins to rumble
when it groans and moans

For only one night more, o dear one
dear friend
until half the darkness
Maybe that's fate
The fate or our friends
That's the way it is measured
Clausula

Step forward towards me, friend
hey, woman, come over here
friend, at the edge of the garden

Don't wake up
the pledge of love
US.COMMENTAIRE: Basse: 'hang', 'suspend'; 'pledge', 'promise'. - Mamali': to miss someone or something which is far away. Apart from mamali', the Toraja do not have a single word for love.

US.STROPHE: This dondi' hasn't been taken up together we aren't keeping it together
US.COMMENTAIRE: Ta': negation, contraction of tang or tae'. Tasitoe-toemo: literally 'that can not be taken together'. Si- is a prefix of reciprocity.

US.STROPHE:
Our eyes are already sleepy
our vision is resting

A tree growing at a field's edge
a tree that gives shelter
in case we are lonesome
US.COMMENTAIRE: Recorded one week before the beginning of the death ritual, at Sillanan, Mengkendek district, July 1993. This took place at 1.00 a.m. In several verses a tree giving shelter and shade (from the root ongan) is associated with respected leaders; in this case, the verse is said by an informant to be appropriate for someone who has given help or assistance of some type. For makarorrong, see also karorrong (Sengo 6b below).

US.STROPHE:
It's fitting that you should stumble
along the length of the road
US.COMMENTAIRE: Sala and sala' (Indonesian salah) mean 'wrong, error, fault, sin'. Posala or posala' mean the opposite, that is, 'very fitting or appropriate'. According to the informant's interpretation, this verse alludes to love for those who are away from home, who have emigrated.

US.STROPHE:
You are the one who is in his hearts
and always in his thoughts

The edge of the sky is overcast
the land looks like choppy water
US.COMMENTAIRE: Mallun-mallun or allun-allun 'overcast, dim, cloudy, blurred, faint, indistinct'. Cf. Badong totemo from the region of Rantetayo (10-13) which also includes the word ti-allun-na.

US.STROPHE:
Turning in all directions as if
when the sun is about to set
US.COMMENTAIRE: Pidun-pidun: Indonesian berpendar-pendar. Several meanings ('choppy', 'turning' 'lonely', 'indistinct'). Both mallun and pidun seem to involve a sense of being partly hidden from view. The informant's interpretation suggests that this verse is associated with persons of aristocratic standing and/or affluence.

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: 4. Of the edge of the sky

US.STROPHE:
You are at the edge of the sky
and we are right here

They say make a bridge of the dew
and make a path of the clouds
US.COMMENTAIRE: Saleu' or saliu' is same as salebu' (Indonesian awan), meaning 'clouds.' An informant interprets this verse as appropriate in cases where someone is thought to carry a message to the land of the dead.

US.STROPHE:
The clouds will be summoned for you
and the dew will be called for you

The bridge is unsteady
the crossing place is bowed

Crossing place of f the lustful one
with unhealthy bodies
US.COMMENTAIRE: Is there a connection perceived between lust/lasciviousness and arrogance? Informants associate this verse with persons who are proud and arrogant, but this may be a euphemism due to the sexual connotations of kura'.

US.STROPHE:
Let us go far into the night
let us disturb the darkness

Darkness that is lit up
illuminated by a torch
US.COMMENTAIRE: roya+i' is 'to disturb', for example when chickens start clucking in the night because of a wild animal.

US.STROPHE:
Don't call us torch-bearers
when we are singing poems
US.COMMENTAIRE: To ballo is 'one who carries a torch' in Veen and Tammu 1972.

US.STROPHE:
Say it is we ourselves
Who stay singing the consoling songs
US.COMMENTAIRE: Here, karorrong ('a song to cheer people up or comfort') is related to makarorrong ('lonely, quiet, sad') (*sunyi, sedih, sepih). This is a good example of the association between a socio-psychological state and a speech event (here, mourning songs meant to bring comfort to the audience) and vice versa.

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: 7. Song of male Bokko and ancestor Sudan

US.STROPHE:

US.COMMENTAIRE: Literally, place of Barikalae'

US.STROPHE:
Then we can be in the same room

US.COMMENTAIRE: According to an informant's interpretation, this verse refers to the feeling of missing a family member who has died.

US.STROPHE: Poor thing, free them from the plow come and sing the katia'

US.COMMENTAIRE: Samban refers to part of the harness of the plow, a rope that ties the harness to the buffalo; it also means 'shackles' and, metaphorically, what binds one to (for instance) tradition, the law, responsibility.

US.STROPHE: Thrown out like old strings coming to lament io' io' indeed

They say that we also say

US.COMMENTAIRE: Sailo' designates a dance which has almost disappeared. In the past it was performed by women in the Rantepao plain.

US.STROPHE:
The pouch of the one from afar

They say he will appear

US.COMMENTAIRE: Name of a bridge on the Sa'dan river. Tumonga 'to rise, to point'.

US.COMMENTAIRE: Recorded at Ledo (Buntao', Kec. Sangngalangi). The singers Indo' Kalang, 37 and Indo' Sulu', 60, are accompanied by the flute player, Ne' Pa' Karre, 60. The songs were translated by Pa'Malingga.

Let us just play here for this one night

MEDIA.LEGENDE: The widow of Ne' Sulo, To' Barana', 2000.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Ladder and door of a house, Baruppu', 1993.

US.STROPHE:
We can't seek a livelihood any more face-down we search the land
It's already written at the time of our birth
The one who is not hard goes there one who doesn't talk much
Meet him downriver at the gate of Heaven
US.COMMENTAIRE: The title comes from a Buginese song. Medalle 'unable to find any money to survive'. Puya: place of ancestors, southward, downstream. This strophe is about poverty.

US.STROPHE:
Content to cross the ocean taking a boat

US.COMMENTAIRE: Ria, in the Paniki region, Buntao'.

US.STROPHE:
We are only scarecrows when we are here

US.COMMENTAIRE: Strophe with an underlying Christian tone suggesting that this life is only suffering and that true life is in Paradise.

US.STROPHE:
Just a little time remains only one more evening

Let us sit for just a moment longer before we stay for real
We'll stop and chew betel sitting reddening our lips
US.COMMENTAIRE: This strophe refers to the end of the funerary ossoran badong when the soul, during its journey downstream, rests for a while on the road to ancestorhood.

US.STROPHE:
A crab coming up from below
a crab tottering along
US.COMMENTAIRE: Sung at night, while badong singers rest. The crab refers to the myth of Lakipadada, who wanted to cross the sea in search of immortality. He asked a pure white water buffalo who was not able to take him. Then, he saved himself by climbing onto a limestone rock. He had been perching there for a long time when a giant sea crab (bungkang tasik) offered to carry him to heaven. Thus, he finally reached the Old God (Puang Matua) thanks to this crab. This story explains the presence of the crab in the death ritual from Kesu' and Nanggala (Nooy-Palm 1979: 149, 300; Nooy-Palm 1986: 249).

US.STROPHE:
Don't think we are happy just because we are playing
It's just us, poor things taking away our sorrow
If we were buried in sorrow if we were covered by it
We wouldn't appear we wouldn't be visible
US.COMMENTAIRE: Song composed by the great singer, Indo' Biri, from Mengkendek.

US.STROPHE:

US.COMMENTAIRE: Refers to ceremonial debts.

US.STROPHE:

US.COMMENTAIRE: Refers to the myth of Tulangdidi, a female hero who becomes a deity. After her death, Lapandek or Tulangdidi is brought back to life thanks to the crowing of the cock. In the myth, the young girl Tulangdidi was brought back to life by the singing of a rooster. This rooster, who fulfilled the wishes of the girl, went to the sky with Tulangdidi and they became divinities. Human beings look toward the sky because these two influence sowing. See ossoran badong, line 1075.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: The body waiting in the central room, first death ritual, To' Barana', 2000.

This is a new version. For the old version, suggested by Pa' Pasolang:
Standing like a coconut tree over there, like a flowering palm tree She/he will be a bridge to the sky, and a bridge to the heavens She/he will be neighbor of God, and will become a divine spirit seated like an umbrella.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Dancers welcome the guests, To' Malolo', Sa'dan, 1993.

This sode-sode to minaa ('exaltation of the officiant') is recited when the officiant arrives at the bua' kasalle ritual. He is helped by the singers on the last line of a strophe. This poem describes the transmission of the skills of speaking and singing.

Kandaure: cone-shaped beaded decoration, made of imported beads of various colors, among them old specimens, such as the dark yellow masak. These are worn by women hanging down the back and are used at various ceremonies. The kandaure symbolizes kinship and abundance. The word is used in the sense of 'exalted, majestic, glorious' (Nooy-Palm 1969: 188-189).

Palisu indicate the cowlicks, which are of high importance to the Toraja. The bodies of humans and animals have circles and centers in some parts (fingers, heads, ears and others). The position, unity and number of cowlicks determine the quality of an animal. Buffalo have six cowlicks. Humans have palisu on the tips of their fingers and at the center of their hair. - 169. Sa'sak, Hemidactylus frenatus, gecko

US.COMMENTAIRE: The means that this person surpasses everyone in the performance of funeral rituals. - 401. Literally 'make a pair with the sky'. The plants here are all vertical like the menhir simbuang where the buffalo is killed the tree planted on the sacrificial field, where the meat will be hung, and so on. These signs, links between sky and earth, images of vitality, may suggest the transformation of death into life, and of meat in shoots, as vegetable growth.

Bua uran: 'rain of fruit' or 'rain of stones', hailstorm, image of the meat swaying in the wind, or the pieces of meat cut up and thrown from the platform. - 406. US.COMMENTAIRE: - 416. He switches direction from setting sun to rising sun rituals. - 420. Pekanene'i: 'to call the ancestors'. Refers to the ritual of reversing the dead, ma'nene', mangngika' or ma'tomatua. The winding sheet (fabric wrapping the bodies) is changed during this ritual. It is the last ritual of the setting sun before moving to the rites of life: therefore, a transitional ritual.

US.COMMENTAIRE: - 426. Kalo' 'bed of a river, ditch'. Patomali (bali): 'two balanced sides'. If the highest setting sun ritual has been performed, it must be balanced by a rising sun ritual of the same level. This passage concerns the balance between the parts of the ritual. In 2001 Ne' Lumbaa comments this strophe: 'he reverses his mast '(dibalikan batena).

US.STROPHE:

US.COMMENTAIRE: Offerings made with bamboo containers of meat and rice for the divinities. These are put in different places. Kuli' 'skin'. Literally, with 'skins' of piong. The area is covered with bamboo offering containers left as signs of purification.

Alo (Berenicornis cornatus) 'crested hornbill', in John MacKinnon and Karen Phillips, A Field Guide to the Birds of Borneo, Sumatra, Java and Bali, Oxford University Press, 1993.

US.COMMENTAIRE: - 21. lute: flexible, skillful. There are various types of social stratification depending on the area. In the north, the highest class is known as to makaka (from kaka 'elder'). The strophe suggests that the singers help the higher class.

US.COMMENTAIRE: Recorded at Tiroan (Bittuang), Saluputti district, 16 December 1993. House celebration given the term bua', although the ritual is under the Catholic authority. Sometimes called a ma'kurre sumanga' (thanksgiving) celebration. Five choruses are invited: three male choruses from Tiroan and Se'seng villages, and two female choruses from Tiroan and Bolokan. Performed between noon and 3.00 a.m., either alternatively or in polymusic. Some declamations (singgi' or retteng) are inserted into the songs.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Map showing where the recording took place, Tiroan and Bittuang. From Peta rupabumi Indonesia, 1991.

US.COMMENTAIRE: This stanza was specially written for Independence Day (17 August 1993) in line with the political context of that time (*orde baru). *Pancasila refers to the five principles of the Indonesian constitution. The syntax and the first lines are original. Indonesian concepts are said to be: Development (*Pembangunan), Pancasila and Independence (*Kemerdekaan) and, in Toraja, Happiness (Kamarampasan) which was rarely mentioned in this way in the old simbong.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Dandan singers at Ulusalu, 17 August 1993. The headgear comprises Indonesian flags instead of human hair.

US.COMMENTAIRE: In the western region known as 'Toraja-Mamasa', simbong was of two types: eulogy to the house (singgi' banua) or love song (simbong kura; simbo'-simbo'). Generally, simbong was sung alternatively, in antiphony, by a male and a female chorus. Men used a percussion instrument called a saro'-saro'.

US.COMMENTAIRE: Refers to the headgear of the simbong singers, made of feathers from rare birds and sometimes from human hair. Patotti or pana'-pana': ornament of human hair from headhunting worn by the women at the maro or during the nani song. (Nooy Palm 1986, The Sa'dan Toraja, Nijhoff: 30). Patondon, patotti: ring, roller, chignon, bun, crest on men's hair. Ma'patondon 'to roll the hair like this'. - 27. Bembe: clear, bright; fringe of goat's hair, tied to a stick. - 31. Names of village from Baruppu'. Suleleng: a rottan hat with copper horns, worn by men for war dances.

US.COMMENTAIRE: Recorded during the bua' kasalle ritual, Deri, May 1993, inside the house in front of the female effigy ana' dara. The to minaa and to burake sang to praise a special woman who was taboo at the ritual. The song is called mangaluk to tumbang. It is a consecration of the tumbang through a type of prayer that praises her wealth, her village, her house, her ricefields, her situation and her kinship.

US.STROPHE: That's why he returns to the highest peak of the mountain. Seated where ma'bua' is performed, he begins to speak, saying 'oh people, be quiet, people, the owner of the district is speaking'. There was a woman, and there was a man. And he said: the one that was to get married was the child of Banggairante and later he returned home to the middle of the village together with that which is planted in three, and with one bamboo container filled with palm wine for building the house.
US.COMMENTAIRE: In this speech (ma'tambuli), performed at dawn, the burake Ne' Lumbaa addresses the deata, speaking and singing at the same time. He tells the story of a divine wedding. He is turned towards the northeast, close to the 'meat tree' (meat for deata), and he holds a small bamboo container full of blood. In front of him are one hundred of pigs which will be sacrificed some hours later. Deri (Sesean district), bua' kasalle kasalle ritual, 1993.

US.STROPHE: That's how he reached the round village and entered the golden ritual field and later, if the words that you speak are quick, it's where the horns of the water buffalo are enough to be frightening.
US.COMMENTAIRE: Pong Banggairante, 'Lord Whose Plain is Large' (God of the Earth), Pong Tulakpadang 'Lord who Supports the Earth' and Gauntikembong 'Self-Expanding Cloud' (one of the gods of the upper world) form a trinity. See Veen 1965, The Merok Feast of the Sa'dan Toraja, Nijhoff: 66-67.

US.STROPHE:
And he said: he thought he was going to lead the water buffalo tied to a rope, but there was no leading of the water buffalo, he said: he performed the rituals of the fine-toothed comb and the rituals of cleansing, enough to frighten the children he gave birth to.
The witnesses to this wedding stood up, each one with the same purpose in performing this highest of rituals.
Continuing with the marriage, looking for the adz of the child of the skillful one, descended from Pongko.

The wedding is complete, the marriage is consummated, this is what is called 'changing places', one man, the son of a carpenter, and one woman; one, the son of Banggairante, and one woman.
Forever respectful and fertile, giving birth to children, children of the lineage, their fingers complete, doing the high-ranking rituals, weeding and seeking prosperity with their hands, and the results of their handiwork increase, and the rituals they conduct keep increasing.
Looking at the faces, seeing the faces of the divinised ancestors, let us go down to the land together with them. Bringing down aluk measured into seven kernels, aluk measured into seven sheets.

Everything comes from the yellow-golden ritual arranged like the roof of a house, like the child of the roof, in other words, the ritual of the cordyline. The trance-dancers gather, those who hold the cordyline move in a circle, it begins again, they sound the zither, they play the flute, the ritual is taking place. This is called Mother of Rice and also Sokko Karare'.
US.COMMENTAIRE: The tumbang are the women who go into trance during the maro ritual.

US.STROPHE: The ridge pole keeps going upward, the bright roof dancing up high, it's not going to the sky, it's going up to Balanda.
US.COMMENTAIRE: Balanda 'Dutch' is the Torajan word referring to any stranger. It was used by the Toraja before the arrival of the Dutch in their mountains.

US.COMMENTAIRE: Ura': part of the body in the form of a thread, vein, artery, tubes. The veins are the swords' nerves. It seems probable, says Charles Zerner, that the swords' nerves were perceived as living patterns, and the blades themselves, made of animate iron, were regarded as alive (in C. Zerner, 'Signs of the Spirits, Signature of the Smith: Iron Forging in Tana Toraja'. Indonesia 31: 101). In 1993, Ne' Lumbaa said: 'Occasionally, the blood does not stop despite the flagellations with cordyline leaves. It happens when the singing is false; if the singing is true, the blood stops immediately and the wound disappears without leaving a scar. If someone else goes into trance, the lines start again from the beginning.'

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Woman on a drum, Maro ritual, Torea, 1993.

US.COMMENTAIRE: Sape-sape to Balanda 'to pick the Dutch'. Sape 'to pick' recall the mythical origin of the ritual, known also as sapean tabang 'to pick the cordyline'. Balanda means 'White man, Dutch, stranger'. Sape-sape could refer to the personal ornaments of the Dutch settler or of the Bugis, their neighbors: glasses, clothes, shoes, weapons, and headgear. These ornaments could have been seen by the Toraja around 1670 at the arrival of Bugis in Toraja country.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Songko', golden headgear of the Bugis of Bone, Ke'te' Kesu', 2005.

US.COMMENTAIRE: Bone and Balanda could be a disguise for the word for divinities. This personification is based on analogies (love of power, extraordinary image). The names of divinities may not be uttered, so the song used substitutes. The Bone headgear is attractive and unusual due to the drawings on the top. The headgear is the metaphor for the power of divinities, in the same way as the sarong (kundai pangka) that people from Bone would wear.

US.COMMENTAIRE: Sape-sape to Balanda 'Pick-pick the stranger' is a refrain sung at the maro ritual. 'Sape-sape to Balanda': recurrent strophe. Sape 'to pick' recalls the mythical origin of the ritual also known as sapean tabang 'to pick the cordyline'. Balanda means 'Dutch, stranger'. Sape-sape could refer to the personal ornaments of the Dutch settler or of the Bugis, their neighbors: glasses, clothes, shoes, weapons, and headgear. These ornaments could have been seen by the Toraja around 1670 at the arrival of Bugis in Toraja country.

US.COMMENTAIRE: Torea village, on the night of 17 November 1993. Every evening the divinities are called through the songs of the men. Now, once down, a man scarifies (mantere) himself and women begin to sing. This song refer to a second type of trance. It is called a 'curing song' (gelong ma'pakatana) and also 'women song' (gelong baine) as it is mainly sung by women.

US.COMMENTAIRE: The stanza refer to the magic that just occurred through the man in trance. Formerly, a man went up to a bamboo on which various blades were fixed. This man went up the bamboo and was sitting up at the top. The image of the hung well in the wind may suggest this. The well is a golden source because this man is possessed by spirits and divinities. The image of an iron bath refers to the ascension to the top of the bamboo through iron, without being hurt.

US.COMMENTAIRE: Recorded at Pa'Padadunan (Sereale, Lombok), 10 November 1993, the day of the planting of the masts. Women are conducted by the to minaa Ne' Lumbaa Kepala. In this second type of trance, the to minaa scarifies while the women sing. These six lines beginning by te inde' have the same beginning as lullabies songs. Spirits are there through a trance and they are considered to bring either the extraordinary, or quietness. Balanda 'stranger, white man, spirit'.

US.STROPHE: Balanda causes us suffering Bone makes trouble Makes trouble up in the hills causes us suffering up in the mountains Which mountains up there? which valleys across the way? The mountains fragrant with pangden the valleys scented with white onions
US.COMMENTAIRE: Both Bugis (invading neighbors) and Dutch settlers disturb and frighten the Toraja: they are considered to be spirits and divinities that disturb them because they ask for contributions. They conduct and govern. Before the arrival of the Dutch, they were thought to be extraordinary. Their skin, eyes, shape and objects were special. For that reason, they use their name as metaphors to signify the spirits, without naming them.

US.COMMENTAIRE: Five houses perform the maro ritual. Then five masts, five groups of drummers, five groups of to minaa, and five groups of female dancers enter the big field. At the same time, varying music is performed, with no coordination between the groups. The songs invite the divinities to descend to the site of the performance. Women go into trance.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Group of drummers and dancers, coming from one of the houses, Torea, 1993.

US.STROPHE: Sound

The masters have already eaten the lords have already drunk the creator has finished
The ancestors have already eaten the forebears have already drunk the elders have finished
The drums have already eaten the gongs have already drunk the flutes have finished
US.COMMENTAIRE: To Tallang hamlet, Torea village, Landorundun, 18 November 1993. Fourth night of the maro ritual. Over six days and six nights several to minaa make speeches in the houses participating in the ritual. The volume of speech is huge: 15 000 lines are included in the gelong maro. Here, a small excerpt from one night, where the to minaa thank the divinities. The four to minaa in the house are: to minaa Ne' Lumbaa, Mendo, Seba, Londong.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Offering to the divinities (paisung) by the burake Ne' Lumbaa, 2005.

US.STROPHE: The lords have already eaten the nobility have already drunk the brave ones have eaten The mothers have eaten the golden necklaces have eaten trance-dancers have eaten The roosters have eaten the male swords have eaten the children have eaten The wells have eaten the wells have drunk the pure water is finished Pass the ceremonial bowl scrape the dishes of the lords and the golden glasses All the spoons in the mixing place collect the golden scraps that will be eaten by the chickens So that the locusts will be fat and the flying ants plump So that they produce many offspring grandchildren and great grandchildren So that they remain conscious in the place of the lamba' tree held in the lap of the cordyline leaf
US.COMMENTAIRE: All the names are in threes, in triads, and they are used throughout the long gelong maro narrative.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Plate on a dulang, used for offerings.

US.STROPHE: Introduction by the to minaa 'This is Bugi', the song of the to minaa. The root of Bugi'. Once sung, we tell the story (disamparanni). We present the journey to the ancestors.'
US.COMMENTAIRE: This speech (ossoran bugi') was given to me in 1993 by burake Ne' Lumbaa (Rindingallo district).

US.STROPHE: Memory the people of Bugi' knowledge of the people of Balanda

And our grandparent Genggong and forebears from whom we are descended
And our grandparent Kullu' and our grandparent Ratte Bubun
US.COMMENTAIRE: Lines 7 to 11 are calling to the local ancestors who are around the village (metamba nene' ullepong tondok). Ratte Bubun is the first to burake, an ancestor of the performer to burake Ne' Lumbaa. Having called the ancestors, the singers search for the origin of theBugi'.

US.STROPHE: I will pose a question to you whom we call ancestors: Are you the owner of the Bugi'? the proprietor of the Balanda? forever the mother?
US.COMMENTAIRE: Ampu ('owner'), Balanda ('Dutch, white man') and Bugi' ('spirit' of bugi') are synonymous; they represent the stranger who brings good things and cures.

US.COMMENTAIRE: - 564. Penaa: breath, from inaa 'soul, spirit, thought, heart, knowledge'. Penaa is the living soul, linked to the social world, whereas sumanga' is linked to the divine world. - 565-566. Literally, the bodies of the lords have gone home/ the wrapping of the owners of the ship. - 568. Tumende' is from tende' or ende' 'move up and down, like dancing' (Veen & Tammu, 1972).

US.STROPHE: Conclusion The to minaa: - It means that the one who is possessed by bugi' has recovered and returned to a normal state of consciousness again. They ask for all kinds of things, a casuarina leaf, earth, water, all kind of things they ask for. - Do they eat it? - Yes, and at the top of the roof. - Do they climb up there? - Yes, at the top of a tree, of a banana tree. - Don't they fall down? - When you are caught by Bugi', it doesn't matter. The one who is possessed falls down into the mud like a buffalo. When it is over, we sing the Bugi' song and they recover when they have what they asked for.

US.COMMENTAIRE: Recorded during a Christian festival for a house, at Buntu Rura, Angin-Angin, 1993. The organizers had invited one of the famous group of Bugi' from La'bo'. According to Tato' Dena', the lyrics are correct and not modified by the church.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Bugi' dance, Buntao', 1993. Dancers dance from left to right.

US.COMMENTAIRE: Kais: a shrub with red fruits (see Nooy-Palm 1979, The Sa'dan Toraja: A Study of their Social Life and Religion, Nijhoff: 229). Danga-danga: a variety of gladiolus, considered to be a divine plant. Used in some rituals, this flower is a metaphor for a nice girl. Simbolong and lokkon: hair bun.

Introduction by to minaa Tato' Dena'
US.COMMENTAIRE: Recorded on 27 October 1993, at Bekak, during the healing pakorong ritual, from midnight to 3.00 a.m. Seven groups of musicians came to entertain the divinity Ruru', responsible for skin diseases. The following day, seven types of offering with rice, eggs, coconut and areca nut were put on the rice barn by eleven families; the offerings were addressed to seven divinities.

US.STROPHE: Answer from the organizer
US.COMMENTAIRE: 'Let's begin the game of the divinity'

US.STROPHE: 'Second bone of flute'
US.COMMENTAIRE: Flute players distinguish three types of piece: those from the fundamental repertoire (buku suling 'flute bone') are the most important. The flute quartet is located close to the rice barn, to the rising sun, located at the place of offerings to Puang Maruru' divinity. The performance begins, in the space, from the East. This piece is paired with the 'first bone'. See DVD/The Argument/Music of the Rising Sun/Music of the Prophylactic Rituals/Instrumental Music of the pakorong ritual.

US.STROPHE: 'Wind'
US.COMMENTAIRE: Grand Father Pollo from Durian remarked about this piece (7 November 1993): 'Formerly, people were sold. Powerful men came to take slaves. Even flautists were sold in Bugis land. When resting at Bamba Puang (on the road to Makassar), they played the flute for their old parents who stayed at the village. They were sold for one ringgit'.

US.STROPHE: Continuation of the wind

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: Group 2: trio of geso'-geso' fiddles from To'Kuang village.

US.STROPHE: 'Sorrow'
US.COMMENTAIRE: Trio of one-stringed geso'-geso' fiddle. Grand Father Pollo, from Durian, said about this piece, on 7 November 1993: 'Sorrow. This is the sound when everything is already quiet and sad. They remember their faults and their sexual relation with other parents'. The piece uses drone and alternating technique (sisonda).

US.STROPHE: Bugis song
US.COMMENTAIRE: Kacapi plucked-lute duet. 'Formerly, we would sing Toraja songs on the katapi luth, but today, it's in Bugis language and in Bugis style, in the manner of the fishermen,who are Bugis'. Grand Father Pollo from Durian (7 November 1993). The Bugis are the muslim neighbors of the Toraja from the lowlands. Song is alternated.

US.STROPHE: Lutes with the soloist singing
US.COMMENTAIRE: The music of this duo is typically Bugis in rhythm, in its use of alternating singers, and in its nasal timbre.

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: Group 4: Geso'-geso' fiddle trio, from Tiromanda village

US.STROPHE: Piece 1
US.COMMENTAIRE: 'It's a mixture, entertaining the heart.' Unison.

US.STROPHE: Piece 2
US.COMMENTAIRE: Unison, with structure: ABCD / ABCD ED /ABCD/ ED/CD'

US.STROPHE: 'Flute bone of the beginning'
US.COMMENTAIRE: This piece from the fundamental repertoire is paired with the first piece. See DVD/The Argument/Music of the Rising Sun/Music of the Prophylactic Rituals/Instrumental Music of the pakorong ritual.

US.STROPHE: 'Following piece'
US.COMMENTAIRE: Using unison.

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: Group 6: Suling flute quartet, from Tiromanda village

US.STROPHE: 'In one breath'
US.COMMENTAIRE: 'Favorite piece', unison, with trills and structure: AB AB (8va) AB

US.STROPHE: Second piece
US.COMMENTAIRE: Use of the octave, unison, with structure: AB AB (octave).

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: Group 7: Suling flute quartet, from To' Barana'

US.STROPHE: Piece 1
US.COMMENTAIRE: Favorite piece (*lagu favorit), using drone, fast. 'It is the sound from the former kacapi'.

US.STROPHE: Piece 2
US.COMMENTAIRE: Soloists are alternating (sikore). The piece is fast. The structure is: AB x4 alternated / CB x2 alternated/ Dx2 / CBx2 alternated.

US.STROPHE: Piece 1
US.COMMENTAIRE: Using unison. Structure: A A B, divided by an octave. This piece forms a pairing with the first of group 5.

US.STROPHE: Piece 2
US.COMMENTAIRE: Piece from the Pentecostal liturgy, using an heptatonic scale, parallelism in thirds, and a binary rhythmic syntax.

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: Groupe 2: geso'-geso' fiddle trio, from To' Kuang

US.STROPHE: Piece for fiddles
US.COMMENTAIRE: Three phrases and a conclusion, with the structure ABAB/CB CB x2/AB AB/ conclusion. Two parts. Many semi-tone and tone intervals.

US.STROPHE: Mother Logo'
US.COMMENTAIRE: The plucked-lute playing and the song are from Bugis culture.

US.STROPHE: Piece 2
Piece 1
US.COMMENTAIRE: Many tone intervals, a piece in unison, with the structure AB AB CC X2.

US.STROPHE: Piece 2
US.COMMENTAIRE: Unison, with structure ABC ABC BB x2 + CC' and conclusion.

US.STROPHE: Piece 1
US.COMMENTAIRE: Paired with the first quartet. Same superposition at a higher octave.

US.STROPHE: Piece 2
US.COMMENTAIRE: Response to the preceding one.

US.STROPHE: Piece 1
US.COMMENTAIRE: Drone, tempo changing, alternation of soloists, tritone, with structure ABAC. This piece is the pair (bali) of piece 1, group 7.

US.STROPHE: Piece 2
US.COMMENTAIRE: This short piece repeats its melody at a higher octave.

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: Groupe 7: Suling flute quartet from To' Barana'

US.STROPHE: Piece 1
US.COMMENTAIRE: Rhythmical piece using drone, unison and alternation of soloists, using tritone. This is the pair with piece 1, group 6.

US.STROPHE: Piece 2
US.COMMENTAIRE: Using drone, not measured, soloist alternating (kore), with structure AB + conclusion. This piece is paired with piece 1, group 1.

US.STROPHE: Piece 1
US.COMMENTAIRE: Measured, using syllabic drone, with structure: ABC + conclusion. This piece is the answer to the preceding.

US.STROPHE: Piece 2
US.COMMENTAIRE: Drone, with augmented second and conclusion in unison. Paired with piece 1, group 5.

US.STROPHE: Piece 3: Bees on the mountain
US.COMMENTAIRE: On a continuous drone, with semi-tones on the augmented quart, trills, conclusion in unison.

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: Group 2: Geso'-geso' fiddle trio from To' Kuang

US.STROPHE: Piece 1
US.COMMENTAIRE: Unison, with structure: AB x2 CD x 3 with conclusion.

US.STROPHE: Piece 2
US.COMMENTAIRE: On drone

US.STROPHE: Ma'dali
US.COMMENTAIRE: Same song as the first turn, but the second soloist begins. Strophes are sung in alternation by the two singers.

US.STROPHE: Indo' Logo
US.COMMENTAIRE: Repetition of a Bugis piece performed in the second turn.

US.STROPHE: Piece 1
US.COMMENTAIRE: Using drone, with semi-tones, and soloist alternation (sikore).

US.STROPHE: Piece 2
US.COMMENTAIRE: Slower, with trills, unison.

US.STROPHE: Piece 3
US.COMMENTAIRE: On drone

US.STROPHE: Piece 4
US.COMMENTAIRE: The number of pieces increases in the third turn.

US.STROPHE: Piece 1
US.COMMENTAIRE: Using drone, ending in unison. The second part is repeated seven times, with the structure: AB x3 + conclusion. Paired with piece 2, group 1 and piece 1, group 6 coming next.

US.STROPHE: Piece 2
US.COMMENTAIRE: Drone, slow, soloist alternating (pa'kore), with the structure AB x4 + conclusion. An informant links this piece to Pa' angin-angin (piece 2, group 1, turn 1).

US.STROPHE: Piece 3
US.COMMENTAIRE: Drone, augmented second, trills, soloist alternating (pa'kore). Low register, with: AB AB BB BB et clausula.

US.STROPHE: Piece 1
US.COMMENTAIRE: Drone, soloists alternating. Paired with piece 1 of group 2.

US.STROPHE: Piece 2
US.COMMENTAIRE: Drone, short, augmented second, with the structure AB conclusion.

US.STROPHE: Piece 3
US.COMMENTAIRE: Unison, first phrase with trills, and B in tutti. Many semi-tone intervals.

US.STROPHE: Piece 4
US.COMMENTAIRE: Drone, soloist alternating, a melody that turns on itself and a melody that ascends. Paired with piece 1, group 7.

REPERTOIRE.TITRE: Group 7: Suling flute quartet from To' Barana'

US.STROPHE: Piece 1
US.COMMENTAIRE: Continuous drone, trills, slow. Contrast between a short melody and a developed phrase from the soloist, going down, with a clausula.

US.STROPHE: Piece 2 'fourth flute bone'
US.COMMENTAIRE: One of the main pieces of the repertoire from 'Flute base' oto' suling. Paired with piece 4, group 6. Tritone, drone, harmonic game between tritone and quint (fa#-do and fa#-do#), melodic ornaments around basic sounds, many small rhythmic values contrasting with the continuous fa#.

US.STROPHE: Piece 3
US.COMMENTAIRE: This melody can be used in the death ritual.

US.STROPHE: Piece 4
US.COMMENTAIRE: On drone in two parts AB and conclusion, with multipart harmony at a second.

US.STROPHE: Piece 5
US.COMMENTAIRE: The soloist style is ornamented, using drone, alternation (pa'kore), minor third and augmented quart.

US.STROPHE: Piece 1
US.COMMENTAIRE: A piece in unison that sounds like a conclusion, repeated at an octave.

US.STROPHE: Piece 2
US.COMMENTAIRE: Piece with a Pentecostal influence, with third parallelism and drone.

US.STROPHE: The rice is swaying here
US.COMMENTAIRE: Recorded in the ricefields: five singers cleaning the ricefields. Tondok Bakaru, Kecamatan Mamasa, 9 September 1993. This first line appears elsewhere: lunda'-lunda' inde pare/tae' den umpendioi. 'Rice is swaying here, there's no one who uses it to bathe'. Lunde may come from lundan 'to lay down while rolling'. During this fertility game performed in the ricefields, boys come to bring the betel nut. They place it in front of the girls. They hug each other and change partners until they no longer want to change and push the chosen girl into the water.

US.STROPHE: Where are the overflowing kernels? making the sound kereng-kereng
US.COMMENTAIRE: In this love poetry, the birds, used as metaphors for the men to come, are named using the wordskereng-kereng, londong dewata (divine rooster), kaloe (cockatoo). Kereng-kereng may be an onomatopoeic sound.

US.STROPHE: So that we may regain consciousness the little bird from Mandar is staying the sekke' bird is flitting about
US.COMMENTAIRE: Sekke' 'small bird'. The Mandar territory is located west of Mamasa. People speak the Mandar language there.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Singers in the ricefields, Tondok Bakaru, September 1993.

US.STROPHE:
They say the pathway is broken
Eh, our friend from bygone days
US.COMMENTAIRE: Pelalanna: pathway or ladder to go and fetch the areca nut. Baisseng, from baisen: parents-in-law.

MEDIA.LEGENDE: Singer in the ricefields, Tondok Bakaru, September 1993.

US.STROPHE:
For a while we have been saying to each other
suppose we will still be living together
if we might be together again
How cleansed our hearts would be again, mother!
US.COMMENTAIRE: Recorded at night on 10 September 1993, at Tondok Bakaru, in a house, five female singers, out of context.

US.STROPHE:
The sun is yellow like a banana
it won't really set yet
unfortunately we have no playmate

The typhoon is coming again
coming to remind those who forget
US.COMMENTAIRE: Barra' 'typhoon'; lembe 'to forget'.

US.STROPHE: there's no one who uses it to bathe
US.COMMENTAIRE: This line is usually paired in this way: Lunda'-lunda' inde pare, tae' den umpendioi. The rice is swaying, there's no one who uses it to bathe. Possible metaphor for love games during the cleaning of the ricefield.

US.STROPHE:
Touching the grass nicely
nudging the weeds nicely
Where are the kernels of the valley making the sound kereng-kereng? Why is there no one awake? hey rooster of the deities

Looking for the betel fruit in the evening
hey, friend from bygone days
They say the pathway is broken
hey, friend from bygone days
US.COMMENTAIRE: Bolu 'areca nut'. There are two types of bolu (ind. sirih): the fruit and the leaf. Both are used, with other ingredients, to chew the betel.

US.STROPHE:
Cockatoo across at Mandar
come, fly over here
let us receive you in our hands like gold, Mother

Descendent of the rolled-up grass
rolling along toward those of the same age
are we not of the same age?
indeed humanity is all of the same age
Do you like dondi'? let us play
This is why we do it we remember death and the long women sarong

Who called the rain?
let it come and sprinkle
they say it's cooling

Our hearts are cleansed again
we have bathed without water
isn't it so, Mother?

O reeds
Bending down entertaining each other
O reeds
US.COMMENTAIRE: Tille 'plant' Themeda gigantes

US.STROPHE:
We are at the mouth of the river
where the water is sheltered
The one who holds the sail stands up
the one who skippers the dinghies
you say 'Safe trip'

So, the sun has risen
we go altogether as one
US.COMMENTAIRE: The village Rantebalakalua, Balla Satanetean, Kec. Mamasa, 13 September 1993. Recorded at night in a Protestant church. The song is sung by thirteen women. Dellek 'rise (of sun)'. Rua in the sense of kena, indicated here as 'so'.

US.STROPHE:
Is this here a ricefield?
They call it a lake of betel
US.COMMENTAIRE: Betel is the metaphor for the boy or the man who is hoped. Pangngan refers to the betel chew made of the betel nut, piper betel, tobacco and lime. Mixed and chewed, it has a stimulating effect and produces a red staining in the mouth.

US.STROPHE:
Supposing that one day
betel is gathered all the way

Who appears indistinctly
all blocking the views?

Roll like a betel nut over here
so we may catch your stars
US.COMMENTAIRE: Tima, from timang 'to receive, to welcome'

US.STROPHE:
Our hearts are cleansed again
we've achieved our desire
US.COMMENTAIRE: Tikaladun, as Indonesian terlindung meaning protected, sheltered, hidden from view, subdued.

US.STROPHE:
We are at the mouth of the river
where the water is sheltered
The one who holds the sail stands up
the one who skippers the dinghies
How happy mother is!
It's a lullaby
US.COMMENTAIRE: Lullaby sung by Ne' Lumbaa, at Kattun, on the rice barn, the 24th may 2000

US.STROPHE:
Quiet, child
This little one here is sleeping, he will sleep thriving, and dream growing big Called by his Creator, herded by his maker So that he may grow big, so that he may thrive

MEDIA.LEGENDE: The mother and the child, Kattun, 2000.

US.STROPHE:
As big as the spring, thriving like the source
Growing, he is held by ritual deeds, thriving, he is supported by ritual speech Growing, he is held by the rites of the comb, thriving, he is supported by the rites of cleansing
When the little one gets big, when the one who doesnt know is thriving

If the child is a boy, if his spirit is like a rooster if he replaces his father and substitutes for he who gave birth to him
He replaces him on the land, he gets his back full of sun for he looks for something for the throat, he goes carrying loads from afar

And if the child is a girl, with the spirit of the cloth skirt when she grows up, when she thrives She replaces her mother, she substitutes for the one who gave birth she accompanies her to the ricefields, And when she dreams of being big she pounds rice in the mortar
This little one here is sleeping, the one who does not yet know is dreaming and when the mother returns, she will bring you what you like, and your tasty milk
